**Reno De Medici S.p.A.**

**€590,000,000 Floating Rate Sustainability-Linked Senior Secured Notes due 2029**

__________________________

Reno De Medici S.p.A., a joint-stock company (società per azioni) established under the laws of the Republic of Italy (the “Issuer”), is offering (the “Offering”) €590.0 million aggregate principal

amount of its Floating Rate Sustainability-Linked Senior Secured Notes due 2029 (the “Notes”). The Notes will bear interest at a rate equal to three-month EURIBOR (with a 0% floor) plus % per annum,
reset quarterly. As of and from, 2026 (the “Step-Up Date”) this interest rate will increase by 0.125%, 0.250% or 0.375% depending on whether respectively, one, two or three Sustainability Performance
Targets (as defined herein) are not certified as achieved by the Testing Date (as defined herein), as certified by the Issuer to the Trustee (as defined herein) (with a copy to the Paying Agent (as defined herein))
on or prior to the Certification Date (as defined herein). See “Description of the Notes—Calculation of Interest.” Interest will be paid on the Notes quarterly in arrears on,, and each
year, commencing on, 2024. The Notes will mature on, 2029.

Proceeds from the Offering, will be used, directly or indirectly, to (i) redeem the Existing Notes (as defined herein) and pay any accrued and unpaid interest thereon, (ii) repay amounts outstanding

under and cancel the Fiskeby Acquisition Facility (as defined herein), including any accrued and unpaid interest thereon, and (iii) pay fees and expenses in connection with the Transactions (as defined herein).
See “Use of Proceeds.”

At any time prior to, 2025, the Issuer will be entitled, at its option, to redeem all or a portion of the Notes upon not less than 10 nor more than 60 days’ notice by paying a redemption price

equal to 100% of the principal amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, plus the relevant “make-whole” premium, as described in this offering memorandum (the
“Offering Memorandum”). In addition, prior to, 2025, the Issuer may redeem up to 10% of the aggregate principal amount of the Notes originally issued (including the aggregate principal amount of
any additional Notes issued) in each calendar year at a redemption price equal to 103% of the principal amount thereof plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any, to, but excluding, the
date of redemption. At any time on or after, 2025, the Issuer may redeem all or a portion of the Notes upon not less than 10 nor more than 60 days’ notice, at par, plus accrued and unpaid interest. Upon
the occurrence of certain events constituting a change of control, the Issuer may be required to make an offer to purchase the Notes. However, a change of control will not be deemed to have occurred if a
specified consolidated net leverage ratio is not exceeded in connection with such event. In the event of certain developments affecting taxation, the Issuer may redeem all, but not less than all, of the Notes by
paying a redemption price equal to 100% of the principal amount thereof, plus accrued and unpaid interest and additional amounts, if any.

The Notes will be senior secured obligations of the Issuer. The Notes will rank equal in right of payment with all existing and future indebtedness of the Issuer that is not subordinated in right of

payment to the Notes and will be senior in right of payment to all existing and future indebtedness of the Issuer that is subordinated in right of payment to the Notes. The Notes will be effectively subordinated
to any existing and future indebtedness of the Issuer that will receive proceeds from any enforcement action over the Collateral (as defined herein) on a priority basis, including the Revolving Credit Facility,
to the extent of the value of such Collateral. The Notes will be structurally subordinated to all indebtedness and other liabilities of the Issuer’s existing and future subsidiaries that do not guarantee the Notes.

On the Issue Date the Notes will not be guaranteed. No later than 60 days following the Issue Date, subject to the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement and Agreed Security Principles (and to

certain significant limitation under applicable law), the Notes will be guaranteed on a senior basis (the “Guarantees”) by Fineska B.V., Eska B.V., Eska International B.V., Eska USA B.V. and R.D.M. Arnsberg
GmbH (the “Initial Guarantors”). In addition, after the Issue Date and subject to the terms of the Intercreditor Agreement and Agreed Security Principles (and to certain significant limitation under applicable
law), the Notes will also be guaranteed on a senior basis by any other subsidiaries of the Issuer that become obligors under the Revolving Credit Facility from time to time (the “Additional Guarantors” and,
the Additional Guarantors together with the Initial Guarantors, the “Guarantors”). See “Description of the Notes—Guarantees.”

Subject to the Agreed Security Principles and certain perfection requirements, the Notes will be secured on or about the Issue Date by first-priority security interests over (i) all of the issued share

capital of the Issuer held by Rimini TopCo S.p.A. (together with successors and assigns “Topco”); (ii) receivables in respect of certain material loans into the Issuer in respect of which Topco is the creditor, if
any; and (iii) material operating bank accounts of the Issuer (collectively, the “Issue Date Collateral”). Subject to the Agreed Security Principles and certain perfection requirements, the Issue Date Collateral
will also secure obligations in respect of the Revolving Credit Facility. No later than 60 days after the Issue Date, subject to the Agreed Security Principles and certain perfection requirements, the Notes will
also be secured by first-priority security interests over (i) all of the issued share capital of each Initial Guarantor held by the Issuer or any of its subsidiaries; (ii) receivables in respect of certain material loans
in respect of which (x) the Issuer and any Initial Guarantor is a creditor and (y) any Initial Guarantor is a debtor (if any); and (iii) material operating bank accounts of each Initial Guarantor (collectively, the
“Additional Collateral” and, together with the Issue Date Collateral, the “Collateral”). See “Description of the Notes—Security; the Collateral.” The Notes and the security interests over the Collateral will
also be subject to restrictions on enforcement and other limitations under applicable laws and may be released under certain circumstances. See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to the Notes, the Guarantees and
_the Collateral” and “Limitations on Validity and Enforceability of the Guarantees and the Security Interests and Certain Insolvency Law Considerations.”_

Subject to and as set forth in “Description of the Notes—Additional Amounts,” the Issuer will not be liable to pay any additional amounts to holders of the Notes in relation to any withholding or

deduction required pursuant to Italian Legislative Decree No. 239 of April 1, 1996 (as the same may be amended or supplemented from time to time, the “Financial Services Act”) where the Notes are held by
a person resident in a country that does not allow for satisfactory exchange of information with Italy as included (i) in the Ministerial Decree of the Minister of Economy and Finance of September 4, 1996, as
amended and supplemented from time to time or (ii) once effective, in any other decree or regulation that will be issued in the future pursuant to Article 11(4)(c) of Decree No. 239 of April 1, 1996 or otherwise
in the circumstances as described in “Description of the Notes—Additional Amounts.”

There is currently no public market for the Notes. Application will be made to the Luxembourg Stock Exchange (the “Exchange”) for the Notes to be admitted to trading on the Exchange’s Euro

MTF Market and to be listed on the Official List of the Exchange (the “Official List”) upon their issuance. There can be no assurance, however, that the Notes will be listed on the Official List of the Exchange
or that such permission to deal in the Notes will be granted or that such listing will be maintained, and settlement of the Notes is not conditioned upon obtaining this listing or permission to list.

**PRESENTATION OF FINANCIAL AND OTHER INFORMATION**

**_Historical Financial Information_**

Topco is a holding company established on June 16, 2021 solely for the purpose of facilitating the RDM

Acquisition through its subsidiary Bidco (which subsequently merged into RDM). Topco, through its subsidiary
Bidco, acquired control of RDM on October 26, 2021, and began consolidating RDM’s results of operations as of and
from such date. Prior to the RDM Acquisition, results of operations were consolidated at the level of RDM, which
was the parent company of the Group.

For the period between its incorporation and the RDM Acquisition, Topco was not involved in any operating

activity except for those carried out in connection with the RDM Acquisition. Therefore, while Topco’s consolidated
statement of financial position as of December 31, 2021 reflects the full impact of the RDM Acquisition, Topco’s
consolidated statement of income and cash flow statement for the year ended December 31, 2021 only includes the
results of operations of Bidco and RDM and its consolidated subsidiaries from October 26, 2021 to December 31,
2021. As a result and unless otherwise specified, in this Offering Memorandum we present consolidated financial
information for (i) Topco, as of and for the years ended December 31, 2022 and 2023, and as of December 31, 2021;
and (ii) RDM, for the year ended December 31, 2021. Due to the change of control, the consolidated financial
information presented in this Offering Memorandum for RDM, prior to completion of the RDM Acquisition, and
Topco, after completion of the RDM Acquisition, are not comparable.

The consolidated financial information of the Group included in this Offering Memorandum has been

extracted or derived from:

    - the consolidated financial statements of RDM as of and for the year ended December 31, 2021, prepared
in accordance with IFRS and audited by PricewaterhouseCoopers S.p.A. (the “RDM Audited
**Consolidated Financial Statements”) including the audit report thereon;**

    - the consolidated financial statements of Topco as of and for the years ended December 31, 2022 and
2023, prepared in accordance with IFRS and audited by PricewaterhouseCoopers S.p.A. (the “Topco
**Audited Consolidated Financial Statements” and together with the RDM Audited Consolidated**
Financial Statements, the “Audited Consolidated Financial Statements”) including the audit reports
thereon.

The above Audited Consolidated Financial Statements are included in the F-pages to this Offering

Memorandum and should be read in conjunction with the relevant notes included therein.

differences between IFRS and other generally accepted accounting principles and how those differences might affect

**_Restatement of Topco’s consolidated statement of financial position as of December 31, 2021_**

The consolidated statement of financial position of Topco as of December 31, 2021 included in the Topco

Audited Consolidated Financial Statements have been restated following the completion of the purchase price

**_Non-IFRS Financial Measures_**

In this Offering Memorandum, we present certain non-IFRS measures and ratios, including EBITDA,

EBITDA Margin, Net Financial Debt, Cash Conversion and Capital Expenditures (collectively the “Non-IFRS
**Financial Measures”).We believe that these Non-IFRS Financial Measures provide useful and relevant information**
for analyzing our financial performance and financial condition. We also believe they facilitate management’s ability
to identify operational trends and make decisions regarding resource allocations and other operational decisions and
use them for such purposes.

Set forth below are the Non-IFRS Financial Measures used in this Offering Memorandum:

    - “EBITDA” calculated as profit (loss) for the period adjusted for (i) profit (loss) for the period of
discontinued operations, (ii) taxes, (iii) gains (losses) on investments, (iv) net financial income
(expense), (v) depreciation and amortization and (vi) write-downs and revaluations.

    - “EBITDA Margin” calculated as EBITDA as a percentage of revenues from sales.


-----

- “Net Financial Debt” calculated as the sum of (i) current and non-current payables to banks and other
lenders and (ii) current and non-current derivative instrument liabilities, less the sum of (iii) cash and
cash equivalents, (iv) current financial assets and (v) current derivative instruments assets.

- “Capital Expenditures” calculated as investments in tangible assets and intangible assets.

- “Maintenance Capital Expenditure” calculated as working and ordinary capital expenditure to
maintain a certain level of productivity.

- “Cash Conversion” calculated as EBITDA less Maintenance Capital Expenditure.

- “Cash Conversion Ratio” calculated as Cash Conversion divided by EBITDA.

- “Pro Forma Adjusted Cash Conversion” calculated as the sum of Run Rate Adjusted Pro Forma
EBITDA less maintenance capital expenditures, excluding maintenance capital expenditures incurred at
our Blendecques mill for the year ended December 31, 2023, but including maintenance capital
expenditures incurred by the Fiskeby Group for the period from January 1, 2023 to completion of the
Fiskeby Acquisition.

- “Pro Forma Revenues from Sales” which reflects revenues from sales for the year ended December
31, 2023 as if the Fiskeby Acquisition had occurred on January 1, 2023.

- “Adjusted Pro Forma Revenues from Sales” which reflects Pro Forma Revenues from Sales for the
year ended December 31, 2023, as further adjusted as if RDM Blendecques S.A.S. was no longer within
the scope of consolidation of the Group as of and from January 1, 2023.

- “Pro Forma EBITDA” calculated as pro forma profit (loss) for the period adjusted for (i) profit (loss)
for the period of discontinued operations, (ii) pro forma taxes, (iii) pro forma gains (losses) on
investments, (iv) pro forma net financial income (expense), (v) pro forma depreciation and amortization
and (vi) pro forma write-downs and revaluations.

- “Adjusted Pro Forma EBITDA” calculated as Pro Forma EBITDA further adjusted for certain nonrecurring items and normalization adjustments as well as pro forma cost savings. Although management
believes these items are unusual, non-recurring or unrepresentative of our underlying performance, there
can be no assurance that we will not incur these or similar costs in the future.

- “Run Rate Adjusted Pro Forma EBITDA” calculated as Adjusted Pro Forma EBITDA, further
adjusted for the estimated run-rate effect from structural cost savings and synergies expected to be
generated from certain capital expenditures initiatives implemented in 2023, and the integration of
Fiskeby into our operations following completion of the Fiskeby Acquisition.

- **“Run Rate Adjusted Pro Forma EBITDA Margin” is defined as Run Rate Adjusted Pro Forma**
EBITDA Margin expressed as a percentage of Adjusted Pro Forma Revenues from Sales.

- “Pro Forma Adjusted Net Financial Debt” calculated as (i) adjusted pro forma payables to banks and
other lenders (excluding any Notes issuance costs) _less_ (ii) as adjusted cash and cash equivalents
calculated, in each case as adjusted to give pro forma effect to the Transactions as if they occurred on
December 31, 2023, as further described in the “Capitalization” section of this Offering Memorandum.

- “Pro Forma Adjusted Net Senior Secured Debt” calculated as the outstanding senior secured debt of
the Group, net of as adjusted cash and cash equivalents calculated, in each case, as adjusted to give pro
_forma effect to the Transactions as if they occurred on December 31, 2023, as further described in the_
“Capitalization” section of this Offering Memorandum.


-----

    - “Pro Forma Adjusted Interest Expense” calculated as the cash interest expense as if the Transactions
had occurred on January 1, 2023.

    - “Ratio of Run Rate Adjusted Pro Forma EBITDA to Pro Forma Adjusted Interest Expense”
calculated as Run Rate Adjusted Pro Forma EBITDA divided by Pro Forma Adjusted Interest Expense.

    - “Ratio of Pro Forma Adjusted Net Financial Debt to Run Rate Adjusted Pro Forma EBITDA”
calculated as Pro Forma Adjusted Net Financial Debt divided by Run Rate Adjusted Pro Forma EBITDA.

    - “Ratio of Pro Forma Adjusted Net Senior Secured Debt to Run Rate Adjusted Pro Forma
**EBITDA” calculated as Pro Forma Adjusted Net Senior Secured Debt divided by Run Rate Adjusted**
Pro Forma EBITDA.

In addition, in this Offering Memorandum we present certain financial information for the Group and the

Fiskeby Group, including revenue and EBITDA, on a combined basis for the year ended December 31, 2022 and 2021
(the “Combined Group Financial Information”). The Combined Group Financial Information is calculated by
aggregating the stand-alone financial information of the Group and the Fiskeby Group without applying any pro forma
adjustments.

The main differences between the Combined Group Financial Information and the Unaudited Pro Forma

Consolidated Financial Information are related to the alignment of the accounting policies of the Fiskeby Group to
those applied by the Group and the simulation of the impacts of the application of the IFRS on the consolidated
financial information of the Fiskeby Group.

For a description of how our Non-IFRS Financial Measures and Combined Group Financial Information are

calculated from our consolidated results from operations and a reconciliation of our Non-IFRS Financial Measures
and Combined Group Financial Information to our results for the periods presented in this Offering Memorandum,
please see “Summary Financial and Other Information.” In addition, to enhance comparability across period, in this
Offering Memorandum, we present certain financial metrics as if Blendecques was classified as discontinued
operations and was excluded from the Group’s consolidation perimeter as of January 1, 2023.

These and other Non-IFRS Financial Measures presented in this Offering Memorandum may be used by

different companies for different purposes and are often calculated in ways that reflect the business environment and
circumstances of those companies. These and other Non-IFRS Financial Measures may also differ from corresponding
or similar terms as defined in and calculated in accordance with the Indenture. You should exercise caution in
comparing these and other Non-IFRS Financial Measures to similar measures used by other companies. The
information presented by each of these and other Non-IFRS Financial Measures is unaudited and has not been prepared
in accordance with IFRS or any other accounting standards.

These and other Non-IFRS Financial Measures we present in this Offering Memorandum should be

considered supplemental to the measurements of performance and financial position that are calculated and presented
in accordance with IFRS, and they should not be used or interpreted in isolation. These measures are not measurements
of performance under IFRS or any other accounting principles and you should not consider them as alternatives to

encouraged to review the adjustments reflected in our presentation of Non-IFRS Financial Measures and
independently evaluate whether you consider each one of these adjustments to be appropriate.

Our Non-IFRS Financial Measures have important limitations as analytical tools, including, among others:

    - they do not reflect the interest expense or cash requirements necessary to service interest or principal
payments on our debt;

    - they do not reflect any expenses related to the payment of taxes, including those requiring cash payments;


-----

    - they are not adjusted for all cash income or expense items that are reflected in our statements of cash
flows;

    - although depreciation and amortization are non-cash charges, the assets being depreciated or amortized

    - they may include adjustments for the impact of charges or expenses resulting from certain matters we

    - they do not fully reflect the impact of COVID-19 on our performance.

**Overview**

We are a leading European producer and distributor of recycled cartonboard, active in the coated and

uncoated recycled cartonboard industry. We operate in the white lined chipboard (“WLC”) and solidboard (“SB”)
market segments, in each case with a demonstrated track record of making our operations more sustainable as both
WLC and SB are manufactured from recovered paper and we actively invest in our operations to reduce emissions,
waste, water usage and other environmental factors. Our cartonboard can be used as both primary and secondary
packaging. Our WLC products are predominantly used, without limitation, in packaging for the food, hygiene and
cleaning, pharmaceuticals and healthcare, electronics, textile and toy industries. Our SB products are mostly used
for the packaging of luxury goods, publishing applications (bookbinding), as well as for graphical applications, such
as for puzzles and games.

Our identity is built on a clear vision centered on the circular economy that guides our activities as a

manufacturer of WLC and SB from recycled materials, and that represents a balanced combination between our
business and the expectations of our stakeholders; see also “Business—Our Production Process—Circular Business
_Model.” Our ambition is to be the partner of choice of all key stakeholders with three strategic goals in mind: to_
offer excellent products and services, to optimize costs and to maximize the satisfaction of our customers, all while
helping drive increased sustainability within the paper and packaging industry.

As of December 31, 2023, we served our customers through a network of ten mills (including

Blendecques), four sheeting and distribution centers, and 13 sales offices. As of December 31, 2023, we employed
over 2,520 employees.

We believe that our geographical footprint across Europe and exposure to resilient end-markets (such as

the food end-market) are key strengths of our business, which we have reinforced through the recent Fiskeby
Acquisition in 2023 (in addition to Eska and Paprinsa Acquisitions in 2021). Our position as a leader in the European
WLC market is supported by our distributed network of mills, our “multi-mill” concept, whereby we seek to be able
to offer similar cartonboard products at different mills whenever possible, helping us meet our customers’ demands
quickly regardless of their proximity to a specific production site, and guarantee security of supply to our entire
customer base. Our distributed mill network is integrated by our “One Company” operating model, which helps to
ensure we have both a local presence near our customers and a platform with the scale and sophistication required
to efficiently respond to our customers’ needs across the continent.

    - **_WLC. In our WLC market segment, we produce cartonboard from recycled fibers for folding carton_**
and corrugated packaging applications. According to RDM Group’s analysis based on data provided
by a global management consulting company, we are the largest non-integrated WLC producer (based
on annual production capacity as of December 31, 2023), with a market share of approximately 27%
for the year ended December 31, 2023 (after giving pro forma effect to the Fiskeby Acquisition) by
volumes sold, in a rather consolidated European market. In terms of production capacity, WLC
represents approximately 79% of our business as of December 31, 2023 (giving pro forma effect to
the Fiskeby Acquisition).

    - We had a total WLC production capacity of 1,350 thousand tons per year for the year ended
December 31, 2023 (after giving pro forma effect to the Fiskeby Acquisition) of which 110 thousand

1


-----

tons was attributable to our Blendecques mill, which we are planning to close by the second half of
2024 as discussed further under “Summary—Recent Developments—Closure of the Blendecques mill.”

    - **_SB. In our SB market segment, we produce SB from recycled fibers for packaging and graphical_**
applications. We had a total production capacity of 360 thousand tons per year for the year ended
December 31, 2023. In terms of production capacity, SB represents approximately 21% of our business
as of December 31, 2023. We are a leading SB producer with a global reach. Following the Eska
Acquisition, we now have three industry-leading SB production facilities (in terms of production
capacity) across The Netherlands and Italy, with the largest SB production capacity among participants
in the core market segments in which Eska operates (which include luxury packaging, bookbinding,
puzzles and games) for the year ended December 31, 2023.

For the twelve months ended December 31, 2023 (after giving pro forma effect to the Fiskeby Acquisition

as if it had occurred on January 1, 2023), we generated Adjusted Pro Forma Revenues from Sales of €844.6 million
and Run Rate Adjusted Pro Forma EBITDA of €157.7 million (representing a margin of 18.7%) and we sold
approximately 1,018 thousand tons (excluding Blendecques). The charts below present the breakdown of our tons
sold by geography, by relevant end-market and by product, in each case for the year ended December 31, 2023. The
following graphs show tons sold splits of the Group (after giving pro forma affect to the Fiskeby Acquisition).

Source: Company information.

As of December 31, 2023 (after giving pro forma effect to the Fiskeby Acquisition), we served over 2,500

customers across our WLC and SB market segments and sold our products, either directly or indirectly, in over 100
countries worldwide.

We remain united by our “One Company” culture and philosophy and believe that the size of our network

and breadth of our geographical footprint give us significant competitive advantages, including greater operational
flexibility to serve our customers and manufacture our products across our network of mills, as well as enhanced
capacity to supply our products in a timely manner and the flexibility to produce our products at more than one mill.
While our network of nine paper mills is strategically located to best serve our pan-European customer base, which
requires localized service, our operations remain integrated. We centrally manage operations, and we are currently
enhancing our ability to integrate operations across our network by implementing the same ERP systems in all of
our mills. Additionally, improvements to our information technology (“IT”) resources have allowed, and we believe
we will continue to allow, us to balance the availability of products across our network of mills, to optimize
profitability and proximity to customers, to protect their security of supply and to mitigate the risks posed by market
volatility arising from changes in the supply and demand dynamics in local markets. Over the last two years, we
have pursued a broad array of technology initiatives including the creation of sophisticated digital applications to
deliver high-quality and innovative products across the entire value chain as well as the roll-out of a comprehensive
digital transformation program aimed at achieving efficiencies through all areas of the Group, including projects on
operations, logistics, procurement, human resources, sales, planning and health and safety. Key IT products include

the internal tools for corporate management performance, managerial reporting, human capital management and

lean manufacturing philosophy, including through new analytic initiatives to enhance quality integration,
procurement, pricing and supply chain savings.

**_Our products and customers_**

We manufacture different types of recycled paperboard, sold as sheets or rolls, mainly to packaging

manufacturers. The majority of our sales derive from resilient and essential end-markets, such as the food
end-market.

For the twelve months ended December 31, 2023 (after giving pro forma effect to the Fiskeby Acquisition),

more than 59% of the end-users of our WLC products operated within the resilient food market. Our SB products
are purchased for use in applications such as producing packaging for the growing luxury packaging market, as well
as bookbinding, stationary, and manufacturing puzzles and games.

We are committed to sustainability and believe that are well-placed to benefit from the ongoing shift away

from plastic packaging and toward more sustainable alternatives. We believe that we have an attractive sustainability
profile, and our commitment to sustainability has been historically supported by a track record of demonstrable
achievements. For the year ended December 31, 2023 (after giving pro forma effect to the Fiskeby Acquisition),
approximately 95% of the fibrous material we used was recycled and over 84% of all materials used consisted of
renewable materials. In addition, we have reduced our water discharges per ton of cartonboard produced by
approximately 15% since 2020.

As our business continues to evolve, we remain committed to strengthening our product portfolio and

offerings by focusing on renewable, recyclable and actually-recycled solutions (solutions with high recycling rates).
In line with the latest market trends, we are directing our development activities toward cartonboard and SB products
that can replace plastic packaging and are safe to be used for food product. We are focusing our efforts toward the
development of renewable and recyclable “barrier solutions” that are fully integrated with the fiber-based material
structure of the cartonboard. Our consistent aim is to promote and preserve the integrity of the packaged product
while ensuring recyclability of the coated and uncoated cartonboard after its use. In particular, the key themes of
our product innovation are (i) plastic to paper, with a focus on safety for food applications and barriers for grease,
water and oxygen; (ii) digitalization experience by delivering WLC and SB designed for e-commerce; (iii)
environmental experience with a continued focus on alternative sources for fibers and (iv) premium experience by
delivering premium materials and bi-colors board.

We are also currently developing a portfolio of new sustainable solutions to be rolled-out between 2025

and 2028, which we expect will increase our production volumes by more than 300 thousand tons per year. We are
committed to increase transparency in sustainability. To achieve this goal, we are pursuing the external validation
of the carbon footprint of our products and undergoing a third-party life cycle assessment. These activities will allow
us to evaluate sustainability claims and prioritize product initiatives with higher sustainability score.

with the scale and sophistication required to efficiently respond to our customers’ needs across the continent.

**_Pan-European, strategic asset base close to customers providing significant competitive advantages._**

We operate in accordance with our “multi-mill” and “multi-country” approaches, which we believe provide

us with significant competitive advantages in our sector, particularly given the highly localized nature of our
customers and the industry. Our multi mill concept represents one of our core operating principles. We aim to
produce our products in multiple mills whenever possible to ensure that our products are available to our customers
in a flexible and punctual manner and in close proximity to their production sites. We believe that the multi mill
concept allows us to adapt efficiently to changes in market demand and the economic cycles of the countries in
which we operate. We believe we have a well invested asset base, in terms of capacity, technical age, speed and
trim compared to our industry peers, which enables us to effectively pursue our “multi-mill” concept. As of
December 31, 2023, we served our customers through a network of ten mills (including Blendecques), four sheeting
and distribution centers, and 13 sales offices. Our mills are located in Italy, Spain, The Netherlands, Germany,
France and Sweden, giving us a pan European and strategic asset base close to our customers. As further discussed
under “Summary—Recent Developments—Closure of the Blendecques mill,” we are currently planning to cease
operations at the mill located in Blendecques, France, by the second half of 2024. Rather than managing each single
mill to produce a single product, our mills are designed, and operate, to manufacture multiple products whenever
possible. As a result, we can shift production of many of our products across our network of mills, which gives us
flexibility to balance the availability of products at individual plants and to integrate production planning across our
mills. We also believe that our multi-mill concept reinforces the benefits that we derive from our multi-country asset
base. By increasing the interchangeability of our mills and the specific types of our cartonboard produced in multiple
mills, we also increase our ability to meet our customers’ needs at each local plant. This allows us to reduce the time
and cost required for product delivery and to be more immediately responsive to customers’ needs and changing
demands, providing meaningful upside in a market characterized by localized preferences and requirements. Our
focus on coordination within our multi-mill network also allows us to monitor and better respond to market volatility
arising from rapid changes in local demand or changes in production at individual mills as well as from potential
supply chain disruptions.

As part of the integration of the Fiskeby business following the Fiskeby Acquisition, we have successfully

applied our multi-mill concept to the Swedish plant. We believe that the multi-mill concept and post-acquisition

8

integration will allow us to transfer production volumes to different locations to reduce delivery times for existing
customers as well as to find new and more profitable markets and volumes.

**_We have historically demonstrated the ability to navigate in volatile environment delivering strong_**

**_financial performance._**

Starting from 2021 and 2022, as part of an industry-wide unprecedented and temporary phenomenon

affecting our entire value chain, we have experienced significant stocking and de-stocking dynamics, which resulted
in a divergence of patterns between consumption by our customers, on the one hand, and supply dynamics in our
product end-markets, on the other hand.

In particular, in 2021 and the first half of 2022, we experienced increased stocking by many of our

customers, which was primarily driven by their need to secure higher levels of inventories to meet expected market
demand and address supply chain uncertainty caused by macroeconomic concerns, such as supply chain disruptions
related to COVID-19 and other factors and heightened international tensions due to the conflict in Ukraine.
Conversely, starting in the second half of 2022, we experienced a decrease in the sale of our products, primarily as
a result of the reduction in purchase volumes by some of our customers who implemented de-stocking policies.
Such customers started reviewing their inventory management policies and decreased the level of our products held
in stock as they prepared for a generally improved macroeconomic environment in 2023 and as a result of a decrease
in sales of their products in certain end-markets, which was driven by several macroeconomic factors, including a
persisting inflationary environment, a material increases in global interest rates and general softness of private
consumption with end-customers showing recessionary behaviors.

We believe the de-stocking trend has now ended, as the stock of WLC in the European market is currently

very low as illustrated by the below chart from the European association representing the paper industry (“CEPI”).

This is also supported by the strong uptick in order intakes that the WLC European market is currently

experiencing, as illustrated by the below chart (source: CEPI), which clearly indicates that the demand is picking
up.

revised our selling prices downward, we have managed to do that at a slower pace compared to our competitors due

**_We play a central role in the sustainable paper circular economy and have developed a record of_**

**_successfully executing our sustainability initiatives. We aim to continue to be a leader in this field and achieve_**
**_our well-identified long-term sustainability goals._**

As a manufacturer of WLC and SB from recycled materials, we view ourselves as playing a key role in

maintaining a sustainable circular economy. The primary raw material used in our manufacturing process is paper
for recycling (“PfR”) and paperboard obtained from municipal paper collection and commercial or industrial
sources. We believe we are the keystone “link” in the circular economy: we dissolve, treat and form wastepaper into
recycled cartonboard, giving it new life and use. Our WLC products are mainly sold to customers in the converting
industry, who manufacture packaging using the WLC we provide, while our SB products are sold to customers in
industries such as printing and bookbinding as well as to converters for use in packaging. After passing through the
end-user, these materials can be recycled and resupplied to us as raw materials for use in the manufacturing of new
WLC or SB.

All of our products are fully recyclable, enabling them to be converted to packaging at a later stage.

Furthermore, for the year ended December 30, 2023, approximately 95% of the fibrous materials we used came
from recycled materials and over 84% of all materials used consisted of renewable materials, enabling us to foster
the circular economy.

In addition in 2022, we implemented strategic initiatives for the management and improvement of the

quality of the water used in the production from the mills of Hoogezand, Santa Giustina and Barcelona, that allow
us to recycle the process water. In 2023, we invested in the development of the Ovaro power plant. These successful
initiatives further improved our water efficiency and contributed to strong operational performance. We have also
started building a new CHP plant in Barcelona to further reduce our GHG Emissions and achieve cost savings,
which we expect will be completed in the end of the second quarter of 2024.

**Business Strategy**

**_Further strengthen our positioning in the WLC market and expansion in the SB market._**

Through the Eska Acquisition and Paprinsa Acquisition, we have acquired three additional production

sites, expanded our SB product offerings, solidified our market leadership on the Iberian Peninsula, and broadened
the geographic footprint of our network of mills into The Netherlands and distribution centers into the United States.
Furthermore, with the Fiskeby acquisition we have grown our market share in the recycled board market, broadened
the geographic footprint of our network of mills into Sweden and became the largest independent recycled board
producer in Europe. The Fiskeby Acquisition provided us with the opportunity to further diversify and consolidate
our position in Northern and Central Europe, enhancing our multi-mill approach, strengthening our ESG profile,
while improving the overall quality of our offering and granting us direct access to brand owners providing volumes
visibility and opportunities to accelerate plastic substitution.

**_Actively integrate our recent acquisitions to extract commercial and cost synergies and operate with a_**

**_culture of continuous improvement to perpetually strengthen our operating efficiencies and streamline our cost_**
**_structure._**

We have identified several synergy opportunities that we are actively pursuing as the process of integrating

Fiskeby progresses. We have also identified various cost savings initiatives that we conservatively believe will
provide us with potential annual gross cost savings of over €36.6 million in aggregate by the end of 2028 (noting
that we have identified additional areas of upside for further cost savings). These initiatives include (but are not
limited to):

    - **_Plant initiatives:_** plant-level operational efficiencies from machinery upgrades / new equipment to
decrease variable costs (e.g., waste, which we believe could yield gross cost savings of approximately
€12.8 million per year once fully implemented);

    - **_Energy opportunities: investment in new co-generation plant and other equipment to reduce energy_**
costs (which we believe could yield gross cost savings of approximately €14.7 million per year once
fully implemented);

    - **_“ExcellenceOne” Program: a program composed of several initiatives such as lean manufacturing_**
philosophy roll-out, process analytics, maintenance, quality integration, procurement / pricing and

15


-----

supply chain saving through digitalization (which we believe could yield gross cost savings of
approximately €1.2 million per year once fully implemented); and

    - **_Fiskeby Integration: alignment of the performance of the overall equipment effectiveness to the Group_**
one, together with price repositioning, cross selling potential and procurement synergies (which we
believe could yield additional EBITDA impact of €8.0 million).

**_Leverage Fiskeby attractive product offering to expand geographical reach and increase customer base_**

We believe that the Fiskeby acquisition has been highly strategic and will provide us with the opportunity

to (i) grow our market share in the recycled board market and become the largest independent non-integrated
recycled board producer in Europe, (ii) enhance the security of our supply, (iii) expand in attractive markets such as
the United Kingdom, Baltics, Nordics and Poland, (iv) serve pan-European customers in a multi-mill reinforced
approach, (v) improve our cost structure with Fiskeby’s waste-to-energy plant that shelters the mill from any
volatility moves in the energy markets, (vi) use the higher technical performance of Fiskeby’s boards to compete
with producers of virgin fiber cartonboards, and (ix) reduce our carbon footprint, as the Fiskeby’s mill uses
alternative sources of energy.

**_Continue implementing our digitalization agenda to strengthen our “One Company” culture and_**

**_multi-mill concept._**

We believe our multi-mill concept and “One Company” culture provide us with tangible competitive

advantages, and we plan to scale up the impact of these key strengths by further implementing our digitalization
agenda. In addition, we believe our digitalization agenda will allow us to further develop and integrate our multi-mill
concept in our SB sector following the Eska Acquisition in order to continuously improve and enhance our product
offerings, competitive advantages and interchangeability with products produced in the various SB mills.

Our digitalization agenda is a comprehensive digital transformation program aimed at achieving

efficiencies through all areas of the Group, including projects on operations, logistics, procurement, human
resources, sales, planning and health and safety. As such, we strive to further expand and improve our product and
service offerings, as well as our manufacturing and service processes. We view digital improvement as a key strategy
to improve our efficiency, innovation and coordination across our operations.

Through sophisticated digital applications, we are focused on continuing to deliver high-quality and

innovative products across the entire value chain and circular economy in which we operate, with a clear strategy
of continuously strengthening our operational efficiency and excellence through lean manufacturing plans and
initiatives.

**_Continue developing new, innovative products to answer the needs of our customers_**

We believe that product innovation is a key pillar of our strategy and we are focused on further improving

our product offering in order to answer the needs of our clients, be on top of secular trends and capitalize on new
opportunities and unlock additional growth. In this respect, we have identified certain strategic themes which are
the key focus areas of our product innovation:

    - _Plastic to paper substitution: working on greater usage of papers for food applications and barriers for_
grease, water and oxygen;

    - _Digitalization experience: working on WLC and SB designed for e-commerce;_

    - _Environmental: working on alternative sources for fibers; and_

    - _Premium: working on creation of bi-color boards and premium materials._

**_Maintain our sustainability leadership and our focus on achieving our long-term sustainability goals._**

Sustainability is central to our business model and our management team. We are proud of our role in the

circular economy and our ability to grow the sustainability of our business alongside financial performance. To
continue to drive this forward, we have identified clear, quantifiable long-term sustainability goals for 2025 and
2030. These goals include the following:

    - _Climate Change: By 2030, our goal is to have reduced GHG Emissions by 30% (emissions in 2020_
equaled 0.495 tCO2 emissions per ton);

    - _Waste Reduction and Recovery:_ By 2030, our goal is to have reduced the total amount of waste
generated per ton of net saleable product by 18% (total waste per ton of net saleable product in 2020
was 181 kilograms per ton) and have increased the proportion of waste sent for recovery to 90%
(proportion of waste recovered in 2020 was 73%);

    - _Water: By 2030, our goal is to have reduced wastewater discharge per ton of net saleable product by_
20% (wastewater discharge per ton of net saleable product in 2020 was 11.06 cubic meters per ton);

    - _Employee Wellbeing: By 2030, our goal is to have increased the employee advocacy rate to 4.5 (the_
employee advocacy rate in 2020 was 3.98);

    - _Diversity: By 2030, our goal is to have increased the percentage of female employees by 30% (in 2020,_
9.5% of our employees were women); and

    - _Responsible Sourcing of Materials: By 2025, our goal is to have implemented a new program to assess_
and qualify all of our key suppliers for all relevant product categories according to ESG criteria.

Additionally, this Offering is sustainability-linked, with a Sustainability-Linked Financing Framework.

Our Sustainability-Linked Financing Framework includes Sustainability Performance Targets for the most material
indicators for our business for 2025. These are:

      - _Climate Change: By the end of 2025, our goal is to have reduced GHG Emissions by 15% (from_
the 2020 baseline of 0.495 tCO2e/ton);

      - Waste: By the end of 2025, our goal is to have increased the proportion of waste sent for recovery
to 86.2% (from the 2020 baseline of 72.8%); and

      - _Water:_ By the end of 2025, our goal is to have reduced wastewater discharge per ton of net
saleable product by 16.6% (from the 2020 baseline of 11.06 m3/ton).

**_Pursue disciplined investments in key focus areas._**

We will continue to evaluate opportunities to optimize and to grow our asset base, with a focus on

disciplined investments that we believe will strengthen our pan-European presence and support the achievement of
our strategic goals. In addition, we will also continue to explore means to strengthen and to extract greater value
from our existing operations, which may include investments in other related sectors within the circular economy
or along the circular economy value chain in which we operate. For further detail, see also “Business—Our
_Production Process—Circular Business Model.” We believe we have a well-invested asset base today and have a_
history of investing our capital responsibly and with a strong return on investment, and have proven our ability to
successfully integrate acquired assets.

**Recent Developments**

**_Closure of the Blendecques mill_**

Our Blendecques mill was shut down from March 22, 2022 as a result of a fire that occurred due to causes

outside our control. Although the fire materially impacted various areas of the plant, causing operations to cease, no
one was injured or killed. While we invested in the reconstruction of the mill over the course of 2023 via insurance
proceeds received from our insurers, in order to address the continued underperformance of the Blendecques mill,
we are currently considering strategic alternatives and currently intend to cease operations at the Blendecques mill
by the second half of 2024. We believe the closure of this mill will improve our profitability, optimize our industrial
footprint and allow us to more efficiently adapt our current mill capacity to temporary changes in demand dynamics
for cartonboard, that resulted in mitigating pricing pressures in 2023.

We estimate that we will incur approximately €20 million of one-off costs in connection with the closure

of the mill, which we believe that we will recover by 2025 by selling related assets and utilizing our more profitable
mills to take over production which previously would have been produced at the Blendecques mill. In the long-term,
we believe that the closure of the Blendecques mill will have a positive impact on our results of operations and
Adjusted EBITDA and free cash flow. In particular, we expect that in the long-term the closure of the Blendecques
will result in an annual positive impact on our Adjusted EBITDA of between approximately €5 million and
approximately €10 million.

For the twelve months ended December 31, 2023, the Blendecques mill generated revenues of €9.3 million

and an EBITDA loss of €14.7 million. The results of operations from the Blendecques mill will be classified as
discontinued operations in our consolidated financial statements starting from January 1, 2024. To enhance
comparability across period, in this Offering Memorandum, we present certain financial metrics as if Blendecques
was classified as discontinued operations and was excluded from the Group’s consolidation perimeter as of January
1, 2023.

See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to Our Business and Industry—The cyclical nature of our industry may

_result in overcapacity which negatively impacts our results of operations,”_ “Risk Factors—Risks Related to Our
_Business and Industry—Any significant damage to one of our mills could cause a production disruption”_ and
“Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Key Factors Affecting
_Our Financial Condition and Results of Operations—Blendecques and Villa Santa Lucia mills.”_

18


-----

**_Re-opening of the Villa Santa Lucia mill_**

Following the standstill of the Villa Santa Lucia plant from August 2022 to December 2022 and then from

July 2023 to March 2024, due to the unforeseen overhaul of the area’s municipal effluent treatment plant in 2022
and the local Italian court decision to revisit the case and further review its operations in 2023, our management
collaborated with authorities extensively to show there were no further issues and we were able resume operations
at Villa Santa Lucia on March 4, 2024.

See “Risk Factors—Risks Related to Our Business and Industry—Any significant damage to one of our

_mills could cause a production disruption” and “Management’s Discussion and Analysis of Financial Condition_
_and Results of Operations—Key Factors Affecting Our Financial Condition and Results of Operations—_
_Blendecques and Villa Santa Lucia mills.”_

**_The Revolving Credit Facility_**

In connection with the Offering and to further support our liquidity, on March 21, 2024, we entered into

the new Revolving Credit Facility, which provides borrowings of €100 million and will mature on the date falling
six months prior to the maturity of the Notes. The Existing Revolving Credit Facility is expected to be cancelled on
the Issue Date. See “Description of Certain Financing and Guarantee Arrangements—Revolving Credit Facility
_Agreement.”_

**_Order Intake Update_**

Based on preliminary estimates, in the two months ended February 29, 2024, the Group’s order intake in

its white lined chipboard (WLC) market segment increased by 46% compared to the same period of 2023 (excluding
the operations of the Villa Santa Lucia mill as it was closed in January and February 2024). Additionally, RDM had
announced WLC price increase of €60 per ton from March 1, 2024. Demand for RDM board remains strong even
after the Group communicated the price increase. Competitors have followed suit and communicated pricing
increases in line with RDM strategy.

**_Performance Update_**

In the first two months of 2024, we have observed (i) volumes increasing, (ii) prices increasing, (iii) costs

generally stabilizing, and (iv) the continued realization of costs savings, in each case compared to the three months
ended December 31, 2023.

We believe that the re-start of the Villa Santa Lucia mill and the expected closure of the Blendecques mill

will both positively impact EBITDA.

Based on the observed year-to-date trends and planned actions, if such trends continue throughout the year

and volumes increase as expected, we believe that Run Rate Adjusted Pro Forma EBITDA for the year ending
December 31, 2024 will be an improvement compared to the year ended December 31, 2023.
