**_Cost efficiency and improvement initiatives_**

During the periods under review, we have identified various cost-saving and improvement initiatives

that have had a positive effect on our results of operations and that could further booster our profitability in the
coming years. These initiatives include:

    - Investing and implementing operational excellence plans in our mills with the goal of improving
operational efficiencies from machinery upgrades and new equipment, ensuring better quality and
higher production volumes, decreasing variable costs and reducing waste. As of December 31, 2023,
we realized €4.1 million of aggregated synergies through these initiatives, out of €18.8 million of
aggregated synergies identified expected to be generated in full by the end of 2028.

    - Dedicating capital expenditures to energy use management, including investments in co-generation
plants and other energy equipment, as the majority of our capital expenditures are spent on energyrelated items and energy is a material driver of our cost structure. As of December 31, 2023, we
realized €5.6 million of aggregated synergies through these initiatives, out of €20.3 million of
aggregated synergies identified and expected to be generated in full by 2028.

    - Implementing our lean manufacturing philosophy by investing in digital tools, such as process
analytics, maintenance, quality integration, procurement, pricing, and supply chain saving through
digitalization. As of December 31, 2023, we realized €2.5 million of aggregated cost savings
through these initiatives, out of €3.7 million of aggregated cost savings and expected to be generated
in full by the end 2024.

    - Developing commercial and cost synergies with the recently acquired Paprinsa, Eska and Fiskeby
businesses, including (i) with respect to Paprinsa, through recipe optimization as well as
procurement, labor, energy efficiencies to increment sales and volumes, (ii) with respect to Eska
Group, through price alignment, portfolio optimization, value engineering as well as capacity
increase, and (iii) with respect to Fiskeby Group, through price re-positioning, cross-selling,
alignment of the overall equipment effectiveness to the Group and sustainable value generation. We
believe that the positive impact of Fiskeby Group integration may produce up to €8.0 million of
synergies through commercial improvements (up to €4.5 million), enhancement of operations and
value engineering (up to €1.5 million) and integration of procurement and organization structures
into the Group (up to €1 million each). As of December 31, 2023, we realized €15.0 million of
aggregated cost savings and synergies through these initiatives, out of €23.0 million of aggregated
cost savings and synergies identified and expected to be generated in full by 2028.

**Description of Key Line Items and Certain Key Performance Indicators**

**_Revenues from sales_**

Revenues from sales relate to the production and sale of recycled cartonboard, mainly through our WLC

where we produce cartonboard from recycled folding for folding carton and corrugated packaging applications,
as well as SB from recycled fibers for packaging and graphical applications.

**_Other revenues and income_**

Other revenues mainly include revenues from services, energy revenues, rental income, grants,

indemnities and income from other miscellaneous items.

**_Change in inventories of finished goods_**

The change in inventories of finished goods relates to production costs and the variation in inventories

during the period.

110


-----

**_Costs of raw materials and services_**

Costs of raw materials and services primarily relate to:

    - raw materials, including wastepaper, wood paste, cellulose and chemicals, as well as materials for
packaging;

    - commercial services, which include costs for transportation and logistics as well as commissions
for sales agents;

    - industrial services, which primarily include the costs of gas, electricity and coal, as well as costs for
maintenance, waste disposal and other miscellaneous items;

    - general services, including costs for insurance, legal, notarial, administrative and contractual
services, as well as the board of directors, the board of statutory auditors, postal and
telecommunications services and costs for other miscellaneous items; and

    - the use of third-party assets through rental and leasing agreements.

**_Personnel costs_**

Personnel costs mainly consist of wages and salaries, social security contributions, defined-benefit

pension plans and other personnel costs.

**_Other operating costs_**

Other operating costs mainly consist of impairments on receivables and other operating expenses which

primarily include indirect taxes and membership subscriptions to various industrial associations and trade bodies.

**_Depreciation and amortization_**

Depreciation and amortization consist of amortization of intangible assets and depreciation of tangible

assets and right-of-use assets.

**_Net financial income (expense)_**

Net financial income (expense) primarily consists of:

    - financial income, including income from subsidiaries and associates, gains on derivative financial
instruments and other income;

    - financial expenses, primarily related to interest expenses on borrowings and financial liabilities,
losses on derivative financial instruments and other financial charges, including commissions; and

    - realized and unrealized gains and losses on foreign exchange differences.

**_Gains (losses) on investments_**

Gains (losses) on investments refer to income from investments accounted for using the equity method

and changes in the fair value of other investments.

111


-----

**_Taxes_**

Income taxes relate to current and deferred income taxes.

_2023 vs 2022_

Revenues from sales decreased by €423.9 million, or 34.7%, to €798.4 million for the year ended

December 31, 2023 compared to €1,222.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. The decrease was
primarily attributable to the contraction of market demand. The Group has not experienced significant losses in
market share, as the weakness in demand was mainly due to a cycle of de-stocking by customers, who have built
up their inventories during 2021 and 2022 due to expected disruptions in the global supply chain after COVID19, and other paper industry dynamics, such as substitution between paper grades and the impact of the Russia Ukraine conflict. As a result, nearly all paper manufacturers in Europe have experienced reductions in revenues
and volumes, which led to price corrections.

Revenues from sales decreased in all three of the Group’s major geographical areas: in Italy by €106.7

million or 34.6%, to €201.3 million on December 31, 2023 compared to €308.0 million for the year ended
December 31, 2022 (ii) in the European Union by €223.3 million, or 31.7%, to €480.5 million on December 31,
2023 compared to €703.8 million for year ended December 31, 2022, and (iii) in the Rest of the world by €93.9
million, or 44.6%, to €116.6 million on December 31, 2023 compared to €210.5 million for year ended December
31, 2022.

_2022 vs 2021_

Revenues from sales increased by €419.1 million, or 52.2%, to €1,222.3 million for the year ended

December 31, 2022 compared to €803.2 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. The increase was
primarily attributable to (i) €232.5 million related to the change in the consolidation perimeter and, in particular,
to the effects of the Eska Acquisition of €155.1 million and the Paprinsa Acquisition of €77.4 million, which were
both consolidated from July 2021, and (ii) for the remaining portion, the increase in market prices that more than
offset the reduction in volumes. In particular, volumes of the Group decreased from 1,274 thousand tons sold in
2021 to 1,216 thousand tons sold in 2022 (that led to a production decrease of 58 thousand tons), or a 4.6%
reduction. However, the Group was able to offset the loss in volumes due to Blendecques and Villa Santa Lucia
mills being shut down (that led to a production decrease of 154 thousand tons) with the increase in production by
Eska and Paprinsa (that led to a production increase of 165 thousand tons), which in 2022 contributed to the
Group performance over the full year, while in 2021 their production was consolidated only for six months.
Notwithstanding the slight decrease in volumes, in the first half of 2022 revenues from sales were positively
impacted by the increases in selling prices implemented during 2021.

Revenues from sales increased in all three of the Group’s major geographical areas: in Italy by €82.7

million, or 36.7%, to €308.0 million for the year ended December 31, 2022 compared to €225.3 million for the
year ended December 31, 2021, (ii) in the European Union by €263.4 million, or 59.8%, to €703.8 million for the
year ended December 31, 2022 compared to €440.4 million for the year ended December 31, 2021, and (iii) in
the Rest of the world by €73.0 million, or 53.1%, to €210.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2022
compared to €137.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2021.

_2023 vs 2022_

Total cost of raw materials and services decreased by €351.1 million, or 37.6%, to €583.0 million for

the year ended December 31, 2023 compared to €934.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. The
decrease was primarily driven by the decrease in the price of wastepaper and the Group’s main energy sources,
namely natural gas, electricity and coal.

Service costs decrease by €195.6 million, from €483.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2022 to

€288.3 million for the year ended December 31, 2023. This increase was primarily attributable to a decrease in
(i) energy costs of €145.9 million and in (ii) transport costs of €27.0 million. This trend was a consequence of the
contraction of market demand which led to lower production volumes.

_2022 vs 2021_

Total cost of raw materials and services increased by €271.0 million, or 40.9%, to €934.1 million for the

year ended December 31, 2022 from €663.1 million for the year ended December 31, 2021. The increase was
primarily attributable to (i) the change in the consolidation perimeter of €155.3 million due to the Eska Acquisition
and the Paprinsa Acquisition, which were both completed in July 2021 and (ii) to the increase in the price for
recycled fibers and other materials used in production and energy in 2022.

Service costs increased by €185.4 million, from €298.5 million for the year ended December 31, 2021

to €483.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. This increase was mainly due the change in the

**_Liquidity_**

**_Overview_**

Our primary sources of liquidity consist of cash flows from operations and cash proceeds from financing

activities. Cash flows from financing activities have in the past included, among others, the net proceeds from the
Existing Notes, drawings under the Existing Revolving Credit Facility, leasing and short-term loans under local
facilities. Our uses of cash include general working capital and operational needs, funding capital expenditures
and meeting its debt service requirements. We actively monitor our available liquidity to ensure it will be
sufficient to meet our short-term and long-term cash needs, and we monitor our working capital requirements to
ensure excess cash is not tied up in working capital.

In connection with the Offering and to further support our liquidity, on March 21, 2024, we entered into

the Revolving Credit Facility, which provides borrowings of up to €100 million and will mature on the date falling
six months prior to the maturity of the Notes. The Existing Revolving Credit Facility is expected to be cancelled
on the Issue Date. See “Description of Certain Financing and Guarantee Arrangements.” As a result, following
completion of the Transactions, our main sources of liquidity to pay our obligations as they mature or to fund our
liquidity needs will be cash generated from our operating activities, drawings under the Revolving Credit Facility
and certain local facilities.

**Capital Expenditures**

We distinguish between (i) maintenance capital expenditures to maintain a certain level of productivity

and (ii) strategic capital expenditures to expand production capacity. While maintenance capital expenditures are
generally carried out throughout the year and require a limited amount of time to implement, our strategic capital
expenditures generally require our production sites to be closed over a longer period of time. Therefore, and in
order to maximize our theoretical production capacity, we have historically concentrated our strategic capital
expenditures during periods when production sites are closed for holidays, during Christmas holidays in
December and, for our Italian plants, in the month of August.

**Quantitative and Qualitative Disclosures about Market Risk**

We are exposed to certain risks associated with the general macroeconomic environment, including

exchange rate risk, commodity risk, interest rate risk, credit risk and liquidity risk.

**_Exchange rate risk_**

The Group’s functional currency is the Euro. The exposure to exchange rate risk relates to sales,

purchases, receivables, current accounts, borrowings and loans expressed in currencies other than the functional
currency, mainly in USD, GBP and SEK. With reference to all currencies except SEK, in terms of exposure to
currency risk in 2023 the Group managed the marginal imbalance between investments and funds in the same
currency by using a natural-hedging approach and by carefully and continuously monitoring market conditions.
As a result, it was not deemed necessary to resort to hedging derivatives. The Fiskeby Group uses SEK as its
functional currency and uses forward exchange rates contracts to hedge currency risk related to their sales in Euro
and USD. As of December 31, 2023, following the completion of the Fiskeby Acquisition, these derivative
instruments have been included in the consolidated financial statements of the Group; since no formal designation
for hedge accounting purposes was made, these derivatives are recognized at fair value through profit and loss
according to IFRS 9.

**_Commodity risk_**

The commodity risk mainly refers to the fluctuations of raw materials prices that are purchased for the

production and energy costs, which impact the margins that we can achieve on the products that we sell. The
nature of the Group’s business involves exposure to fluctuations in the prices of electricity, natural gas and certain
chemical products derived from petroleum (such as latexes) and fibrous raw materials. Most contractual
relationships with customers involve a transfer of the price risk of the raw materials to the customer. In order to
mitigate the price risk where the transfer is not foreseen, the price lists with customers are reviewed on a quarterly
basis. Natural gas supply contracts are usually agreed for total requirements at a fixed price and are negotiated at
least three months before the supply period, and sometimes for longer periods in relation to the supply period.
Electricity is purchased partly at a fixed price, and partially indexed according to the values of continental
electricity markets as published by the bodies responsible for these markets. In order to contain possible price
pressure on raw materials, the Group aims to diversify its suppliers and its supply markets. As of the date of the
statement of financial position there are no derivative instruments held to commodity risk.

**_Interest rate risk_**

Interest rate risk mainly refers to the Group’s exposure to changes in cash flows due to fluctuation in

market interest rates, with particular reference to the interest expense outflows paid on financial debt. As of
December 31, 2023, more than 70% of the Group’s financial debt was represented by the Existing Notes bearing
an interest cost at a rate equal to three-month EURIBOR (with a 0% floor) plus 5.25% per annum, reset quarterly.
More than 20% of the Group’s financial debt was represented by the Fiskeby Acquisition Facility, bearing an
interest cost at a rate equal to six-month EURIBOR (with a 0% floor) plus 3.00% per annum. The Group is also
party to a SEK-denominated credit line granted by Nordea Bank in Sweden, which amounted to €19.3 million as
of December 31, 2023.

The Group is exposed to interest rate risk in relation to the debt instruments that bear a variable interest

rate and are therefore subject to volatility in market rates, which could impact the Group’s income and cash flow
statements. As of December 31, 2023, the Group was mainly exposed to interest rate risks through the Existing
Notes and the Fiskeby Acquisition Facility. See “Capitalization.” To hedge its exposure to the Existing Notes, in
2023, the Group entered into a zero-cost interest rate collar derivative financial instruments with BNP Paribas for
a notional amount of €220 million (the “Collar”). The Collar has a cap rate of 3.972%, a floor rate of 2.68%. The
Group did not hedge the financial liability associated with the Fiskeby Acquisition Facility. In connection with
the Transactions, the Group will repay in full and cancel the Existing Notes and the Fiskeby Acquisition Facility.
See “Use of Proceeds.”

An increase or reduction of 25 basis points in Euribor rates would result in a related increase or decrease

of finance expense of €871 thousand in 2024 and €1.9 million over the residual maturity of the Existing Notes.

Please refer to Note 23 to the Topco Audited Consolidated Financial Statements relating to “Current and

Non-Current payables to banks and other lenders” for a detailed description of our long-term financial debt.

**_Credit risk_**

Credit risk is essentially derived from receivables from customers. The Group’s exposure to credit risk

is influenced mainly by the individual characteristics of each customer. However, management also considers
broader factors that may impact the overall customer base, such as industry and country-specific default risks. To
mitigate the credit risk related to commercial counterparties, and therefore domestic and foreign customers, the
Group’s operating companies have put in place procedures aimed at ensuring that product are sold to customers
who are deemed reliable according to the Group’s standard payment and delivery conditions. This risk, which
takes the form of the possibility that the counterparty does not fulfill its contractual obligations is mitigated
through constant monitoring of each Group company’s commercial exposure and the collection times of
receivables. The amount of financial assets considered of doubtful recoverability is not significant; in any case it
is covered by appropriate allocations to the provision for doubtful receivables. For a complete description of the

125


-----

Group’s trade receivables gross and net of the provision for bad and doubtful receivables, please refer to Note 3
to the Topco Audited Consolidated Financial Statements.

**_Liquidity risk_**

Liquidity risk is the risk that arises in relation to the Group’s ability to meet obligations under our

financial liabilities. Prudent management of liquidity risk stemming from the Group’s ordinary operating
activities entails maintaining sufficient levels of cash holdings, short-term securities and funding through
adequate credit lines. The Group strives to maintain an adequate stand-by credit lines in order to finalize contracts
and collect invoices, to an extent that ensures financial flexibility, including the Existing Revolving Credit Facility
Agreement, which was fully undrawn as of December 31, 2023. As of December 31, 2023, the Net Financial Debt
of the Group was equal to €545.5 million, with wide margins to satisfy all reasonable financial requirements.

**Use of Accounting Estimates**

The preparation of the Audited Consolidated Financial Statements and the related notes in accordance

with IFRS requires management to make estimates and assumptions that affect the reported amounts of assets
and liabilities and the disclosure of contingent assets and liabilities at the reporting date. The estimates and
assumptions used are based on experience and other factors that are considered to be relevant. Actual results could
differ from those estimates. Estimates are used to measure any provisions for doubtful receivables, inventory
obsolescence, depreciation and amortization, write-downs, employee benefits, restructuring funds, taxes, other
provisions, funds, and valuations of derivative instruments. Estimates and assumptions are reviewed periodically,
and the effects of any changes are recognized in the income statement in the period in which the estimate is
revised (if the revision affects only that period) or in the period of the revision and future periods (if the revision
affects both current and future periods). In this respect, the situation caused by the present economic and financial
crisis has led to the need to make assumptions regarding future performance which are characterized by significant
uncertainty; as a consequence, therefore, actual future results may differ from the estimates. Although not
foreseeable at present, this could have a significant effect on the carrying amounts of the items in question.

The valuation methods and the main assumptions used by management in applying accounting standards

which relate to the future development of operations are described below. These methods and assumptions may
have significant effects on the amounts recognized in the consolidated financial statements, meaning that
adjustments may need to be made in future years, with similarly significant effects on these amounts.

The following is a brief description of the accounting policies that entail the greatest extent of

management subjectivity in calculating estimates, and for which a change in the underlying conditions and
assumptions could have a significant impact on the Audited Consolidated Financial Statements. For a more
detailed description of our significant accounting policies, please refer to the Audited Consolidated Financial
Statements included elsewhere in this Offering Memorandum.

_Trade and other receivables_

Trade and other receivables are initially measured at the fair value of the amount to be received.

Subsequent adjustments are made to account for any write-downs. Non-current trade and other receivables are
subsequently measured at amortized cost.

_Derivatives_

According to IFRS 9, derivative financial instruments consist of assets and liabilities measured at fair

value and eligible for hedge accounting treatment only if the following requirements apply:

    - the hedging relationship is formally designated and documented at its inception;

    - the hedge is expected to be highly effective;

126


-----

    - effectiveness can be reliably measured;

    - the hedge is highly effective throughout the financial reporting periods for which it is designated.

When derivative instruments qualify for hedge accounting, the following accounting treatment applies:

    - for a fair-value hedge (e.g. where a derivative instrument is designated as a hedge of the exposure
to changes in the fair value of assets or liabilities yielding or bearing a fixed rate), the derivative
instrument is measured at fair value and any gain or loss is recognized in the income statement. At
the same time, the carrying amount of the hedged assets or liabilities is adjusted to reflect the
changes in fair value with respect to the hedged risk;

    - for a cash flow hedge (e.g. where a derivative instrument is designated as a hedge of the exposure
to variability in the cash flows of assets or liabilities due to variations in exchange rates), the changes
in fair value of the instrument are initially recognized in a dedicated equity reserve in “Other
components of comprehensive income” and are subsequently reclassified to the income statement
in line with the effects of the hedged transaction on profit or loss.

If hedge accounting cannot be applied, the gains or losses from the fair value measurement of derivative

financial instruments are recognized immediately in the income statement.

_Taxes_

Current income taxes are based on an estimate of the taxable income for the year and based on the

applicable regulatory framework in the countries where the Group operates. The expected liability is recognized
under “Current taxes” net of any payments carried out in advance or withholding tax incurred.

Deferred tax assets and liabilities reflect the temporary differences between the carrying amount of an

asset or liability and its tax base. “Deferred tax liabilities” consist of deferred tax liabilities arising from temporary
differences which will be taxed in future years in accordance with prevailing tax legislation. “Deferred tax assets”
consist of taxes which, despite being recoverable in future years, refer to the current year and are recognized
where it is probable that future taxable income will be sufficient to absorb their recovery. Deferred tax liabilities
were offset by deferred tax assets where conditions specified in IAS 12 were met, notably where the two items
relate to income taxes levied by the same tax authority and where there is a legally enforceable right to offset in
this manner.

Income taxes are recognized in the income statement unless they relate to items directly credited or

charged to shareholders’ equity. in which case the tax effect is recognized directly in that item. Deferred tax assets
are recognized for the carryforward of unused tax losses where it is probable that future taxable income will be
available against which the unused tax losses can be used. Reno De Medici S.p.A. and some of its Italian
subsidiaries (R.D.M. Ovaro S.p.A. and R.D.M. Magenta S.r.l.) participated in the national tax consolidation
scheme pursuant to Article 117 et seq. of the Consolidated Income Tax Act (TUIR). Reno De Medici S.p.A. acts
as the consolidating company and becomes a single taxable base for the group of adhering companies, thereby
enabling this group to offset taxable income against tax losses in a single tax return. Each company participating
in the national tax consolidation agreement transfers its taxable income or tax loss to the consolidating company.

The subsidiary RDM Blendecques S.A.S is also part of the national tax consolidation agreement that

includes the subsidiary R.D.M. Marketing France S.A.S. on the basis of French “Article 223a of the General Tax
Code.”

_Impairment test_

According to IAS 36, at each reporting date, the Group reviews the carrying amount of its tangible and

intangible assets with a finite useful life to assess whether these assets may have lost value (impairment

127


-----

indicators). If the carrying amount exceeds the recoverable amount, the asset is described as impaired. Where it
is not possible to estimate the recoverable amount of an individual asset, the Group estimates the recoverable
amount of the cash-generating unit to which the asset belongs.

The recoverable amount is the higher of fair value less costs to sell and value in use. The fair value is

estimated by taking into account the provisions contained in accounting standard IFRS 13 Fair Value
Measurement. In estimating the value in use, expected future cash flows are discounted to present value using a
post-tax discount rate that reflects current market assessments of the time value of money and the risks specific
to the asset.

If the estimated recoverable amount of an asset (or cash-generating unit) is less than its carrying amount,

the carrying amount is reduced to the recoverable amount. The resulting impairment loss is recognized in the
income statement. Except for goodwill, when there is no longer any reason for an impairment loss to be
recognized, the carrying amount of an asset (or cash-generating unit) is increased to a new carrying amount based
on its estimated recoverable value, which may not exceed the net carrying amount that would have been
determined if no impairment loss had been recognized. The reversal of the impairment loss is recognized in the
income statement.

Goodwill and intangible assets with an indefinite useful life are tested for impairment on an annual basis,

or more frequently if there is any indication that an asset may be impaired.

**INDUSTRY**

**Introduction**

We manufacture white-lined chipboard WLC, a type of coated board used mainly for the production of

folding cartonboard packaging. We are also active in the production of SB for packaging and other applications, such
as luxury packaging, toys, books and stationary products. Both WLC and SB are manufactured from recovered paper
(“RCP”). According to RDM Group’s analysis based on data provided by a global management consulting company,
we are the largest non-integrated European manufacturer of white lined chipboard by production capacity (with a
capacity of 1,350 thousand tons per annum, pro forma for Fiskeby Acquisition and including Blendecques), the largest
producer of coated recycled cartonboard in Italy and in the Iberian Peninsula by production capacity, and the leader
by production capacity in Europe among non-integrated producers in the SB market (with a capacity of 360,000 tons).

**Folding Cartonboard Market**

**_Introduction_**

According to production capacity figures provided by a global management consulting company, folding

cartonboard manufacturing capacity expected for 2023 was approximately 8.7 million tons per annum in Europe as of
July 31, 2023. This total capacity is split between different paper grades including (i) WLC, which represents 48% of
the total capacity, (ii) FBB, which represents 46% of the total capacity, and (iii) solid bleached sulphate (“SBS”),
which represents 6% of the total capacity. WLC grades are manufactured from recycled papers and are referred to as
recycled grades whereas FBB and SBS grades are manufactured from virgin fibers and are referred to as virgin grades.

Cartonboard is used in a variety of industrial and commercial applications across both food and non-food

end-markets. Although cartonboard is widely used across industries, each of the types of paper grades has unique
properties that make it particularly suitable for certain specific uses.

    - WLC is used in a wide range of applications which includes cereals, dry foods, frozen and chilled foods,
detergent and pharmaceutically supported beauty products, confectionery outers, toiletries, household
goods, electrical, engineering products, car spares, do-it-yourself products, gardening, toys and games.
In addition, WLC is available to provide fat resistance and other barrier properties when specially treated,
which can make it suitable for use in fast food, pet food and soap packaging.

    - FBB is used in applications such as cosmetics, chocolate and sugar confectionery, medical and
healthcare, toiletries, dry foods, frozen and chilled foods, coffee and tea, biscuits and baked goods,
clothing, toys, games and photographic products.

    - SBS has excellent printing, structural design and embossing characteristics and is accordingly used in
luxury products and for products where hygiene and preservation of a product’s aroma or flavor is
critical, such as packaging for perfumes, cosmetics, chocolates, pharmaceuticals, frozen foods and
cigarettes.

**_WLC Products Overview_**

WLC is comprised of multiple layers to enhance its rigidity, aesthetic qualities and other attributes. WLC’s

middle layers consist of recycled pulp made from mixed recovered papers or used cartonboard and containerboard
between a top layer and a back layer. The top layer is typically either pulp made from selected white-grade recovered

130


-----

paper or bleached chemical pulp. Selected recovered paper can also be used for the back layer. The overall recycled
content of WLC pulp typically varies from approximately 80% to 100%, as virgin pulp may be added to enhance
structural integrity. The top surface of WLC will typically have two or three layers of white pigment coating to allow
for brighter images and coloring when the cartonboard is printed on by customers, and the back layer may have a
coating of white pigment or may be left unpigmented, resulting in a grey or brown hue depending on its exact
recycled-fiber composition.

WLC is produced on board machines in several stages. Firstly, a dilute suspension of cellulose fiber (pulp)

in water is formed into a thin layer of entangled fibers on a moving plastic mesh, known as the wire. Some of the
water drains away and additional layers of pulp are added to achieve the desired grammage, thickness and composition
of the cartonboard. The remaining water is extracted by pressing and drying the board; this process results in inter-fiber
bonding that gives the recycled cartonboard its strength and rigidity. The board may then be coated if applicable to
enhance the whiteness, smoothness and surface finish for printing, varnishing and general appearance. Finally, there
are a number of finishing operations that take place such as slitting, reeling, sheeting, labelling, palletizing and
wrapping with moisture resistant material for storage and distribution.

**_WLC Industry Fundamentals_**

_Macro drivers and industry trends_

The push for sustainability from the market is greater than it has ever been before. Accordingly, the packaging

industry is evolving and increasingly substituting single-use plastic products with recyclable fiber-based alternatives.

Industry sources suggest that the current macroeconomic outlook is constructive for the WLC market and

support a strong link between demand for packaging, overall economic health and increasing gross domestic product,
as growth of disposable income and consumer spending as well as industrial production result in increased
consumption of packaging products.

The overall landscape for the packaging industry has been impacted by general demographic and lifestyles

trends, including growing preference for sustainable packaging among consumers, increasing demand for take-away
and home deliveries, and the growth in e-commerce. These trends support demand for cartonboard packaging, which
we believe will also increasingly benefit from trends favoring lighter-weight and reduced packaging, reflecting the
general focus on reducing packaging financial costs and negative environmental impacts.

For example, Coca-Cola has started replacing plastic film wrap with cartonboard multipack packaging and

Garnier has relaunched its “Ultra Doux” line of shampoos in a solid bar format encased in recyclable cardboard
packaging.

Despite the impact of these factors, we believe plastics and reusable transit packs will continue to compete

with cartonboard packaging, especially in more established markets and for applications that involve direct contact
with food. The future competitiveness of recycled fiber-based packaging will depend on innovation, product
development, cost and the industry’s ability in general to respond to changing market requirements.

_Legislation_

Directives regarding the packaging industry are an important factor driving plastic substitution trends and

providing attractive market opportunities for new solutions.

Over the past years, the European Union has conducted a review of key fiber-based industry regulations. For

instance, the single-use plastics directive (“SUPD”), which bans or enforces restrictions on several single-use plastic
items, has been reviewed and its scope has been broadened, such that biodegradable and bio-based plastics are
considered to be plastic under the directive. The directive set a collection target of 90% recycling for SUPD bottles
by 2029 (with an interim target of 77% by 2025). Another important directive is the PPWD, that the European
Commission originally proposed to revise in November 2022. On March 4, 2024 the European Council and the
Parliament reached agreed upon terms, which are pending formal adoption by both institutions. The revision aims at
restricting the use of single use plastic, such as plastic packaging for food and beverages and cosmetics and toiletry

131


-----

products. The amendments excluded re-use targets and re-fill obligations, which were included in initial drafting and
which could have had an adverse effect on fiber based products.

_Emerging Trends_

Industry data suggests that there are notable differences in the way the end market segments served by the

packaging industry are evolving:

    - _Food segment: demographic changes and consumer trends, particularly the growing preference for_
convenience, are driving innovation in packaging within this segment, although overall demand remains
steady. The potential to replace plastic packaging represents a significant opportunity for us, which has
been driven, in part, by restrictions on the use of plastic, retailers’ sustainability targets and increasingly
favorable consumer sentiment towards sustainability.

    - _Pharma & Beauty segment: packaging demand is expected to grow steadily within this segment, with_
evolution driven by increased personal spending and an ageing population.

    - _Food Service segment: growth driven by increasing spending on take-away and delivery food, influenced_
also from COVID-19 imposed closures and contingency measures to limit social interaction.

    - _Retail segment: e-commerce expansion increased retail packaging demand, despite demand generally_
mirroring the macroeconomic backdrop.

    - _Graphical & Cigarette segment: increased awareness of the dangers of smoking is leading to a decline_
in the number of smokers worldwide, resulting in a shrinking market for this segment.

_Customer Base_

In Europe, the customer base for folding carton board is fragmented, with more than 500 converters and the

largest five representing only around 30% of the regional capacity. Converters are located throughout Europe in order
to be closer to brand owners — large global consumer goods or food companies — who buy finished or semi-finished
packaging for their consumer goods and food products. Converters supply the final packaging products to the brand
owners, who typically work with few to several suppliers and have strong power in the value chain. RDM also sells
directly to brand owners in some instances, and we see partnerships with brand owners as an attractive avenue to
accelerate plastic substitution trends. Key purchasing criteria for converters and ultimately brand owners depend on
the end-use and on quality requirements. Typically, stiffness, smoothness and strength are the key quality properties
for cartonboard. Brightness can also be a key quality parameter when printability is important. Sustainability is also
playing an increasingly important role within key purchasing criteria. Local brands and smaller converters usually
make their purchasing decisions based on availability, cost and suitability for their machinery, whereas higher-end
brands tend to focus on quality over costs.

_Pricing Dynamics_

Following the COVID-19 pandemic, the cartonboard and paperboard packaging industry, including WLC

experienced from a series of unprecedented but temporary phenomena which impacted the entire value chain.

The second half of 2021 and the first half of 2022 were characterized by severe supply chain disruptions

caused by the COVID-19 pandemic which contributed to an unprecedented increase in the cost of raw materials and
energy, which were then passed on to customers on the back of a strong demand for packaged goods. These factors,
together with other macroeconomic concerns, including the heightened international tensions due to the conflict in
Ukraine, led certain of our customers to secure higher levels of inventory, to meet expected market demand and
address supply chain uncertainty.

The second half of 2022 and the first three quarters of 2023 have seen an inventory correction as supply chain

disruptions sparked by COVID-19 eased and the balance between packaged goods and services were restored to prepandemic levels. Customers started reviewing their inventory management policies and decreased the level of WLC
products held in stock, primarily in order to realign inventories to historical levels, reduce the cost of maintaining
higher-than-usual inventory levels, and as a result of a decrease in sales of their products in certain end-markets, which
was driven by several macroeconomic factors, including a persistent inflationary environment and material increases
in global interest rates which led to a general decrease of private consumption with end-customers showing
recessionary behaviors.

Notwithstanding the evolution and volatility of recycled fiber prices in recent years post-pandemic described

above, producers in the WLC industry have historically been able to pass through increases in input cost to customers
and thereby preserve their spread (defined as difference between selling and input prices), even in periods of rapid
and significant cost increases.

Moreover, the graph below shows that while sale prices, old corrugated containers prices and spread have

there has been a general strong long-term trend toward increasing spreads over time.

There are several reasons behind this long-term historical spread upward trend, both related to structural

features of the market and to the companies operating in the sector. These include:

  - the market structure of the industry, where certain large players such as RDM, which has over 25% market

  - no material new capacity is expected in core markets;

**Solidboard Market**

**_Introduction_**

We are active in the production and supply of recycled SB with our mill located in Ovaro and through the

Eska Group. As a result, our overall SB production capacity amounts to approximately 359,000 tons per year, making
us the largest producer of SB in Europe among non-integrated producers (i.e., producers who do not also operate as
converters).

Industry sources expect the global SB market to reach around 8.4 million tons by 2027. This growth is

primarily driven by: (i) strong opportunities in luxury packaging, an end-market expected to grow at a CAGR of
approximately 1.7% to 2027, as a result of increasing disposable incomes worldwide and increasing requests for
innovative, attractive and high quality products; (ii) developments in bookbinding and stationery, driven by rising
literacy rates in emerging markets and rising incomes in Asia; and (iii) increasing popularity in puzzles and games
due to an increased desire to disconnect from the digital world and from the innovative development of this category.

**_SB Products Overview_**

SB is a technically complex paper board grade with unique features, which is obtained through an integrated

production process — made of six intermediate steps — in which three layers are laminated in line:

    - _Pulp Preparation: recycled paper is mixed with water and turned into pulp, with existing impurities_
extracted from the mix through multiple steps using several specific techniques.

    - _Forming: water from the pulp is drained out and the pulp is carried on metal wires forming a paper web._
At the end of this process, almost 70% of the water is extracted.

    - _Press: up to 20% of the water is then extracted via a press system of nips made of rolls pressing against_
each other.

    - _Drying: the dryer section further desiccates the web through a series of internally steam heated cylinders_
that evaporate the moisture to reach the final moisture content of the board.

    - _Laminating: two layers of paper are laminated to the board to provide the required capabilities and then_
they are rolled on a reel.

    - _Cutting: the laminated SB is cut into sheets of the required size, packed and shipped to a printer or_
converter.

In addition to the three laminated layers, in accordance with each customer’s request and the characteristics

of the specific end market, it is possible to also add white offset paper lamination, barrier lamination and/or backside
lamination. Customization is relevant in SB as the board’s quality is determined by the degree to which the customer’s
technical requirements are met.

136


-----

Source: Company information.

In general, the overall thickness of the three layers can range from 1.0 to 4.0mm, with the central thicker

layer accounting for 50-60% and the two external layers equally to 20-25% each.

**_Solidboard Industry Fundamentals_**

SB is a frontrunner in the megatrend towards 100% sustainable packaging products and operations. Being

sustainable is a key purchasing criterion for customers’ choices, driving the demand for SB:

    - Europe is leading the sustainability megatrend, but North America and Asia are also increasing their
focus, creating new opportunities.

    - The increased awareness of the hazards of plastics among consumers is pressuring luxury brands to use
plastic-free and sustainable packaging. In the consumer and luxury business sector there are already
more than 400 major companies that have declared their commitment towards the reduction of plastics
usage.

In general, attention to and awareness of the benefits of recycling is increasing in media, politics and

corporations and within society at large. Developing countries are shifting their attention towards introducing and
improving their recycling and collection programs as opposition mounts against products with poor recycling rates
(e.g., single use plastics).

Sustainability is not the only fundamental that we believe supports the future success of the SB sector. In

particular, the global luxury market is bouncing back after suffering during the COVID-19 pandemic with an expected
annual growth pace between 3-5% until 2027. The grade is used in high-end packaging for several luxury products
including jewelry, fashion, wine and spirits, perfumes and cosmetics, as well as consumer electronics and fine foods.
These end markets also represent a major force in product innovation, as luxury brands constantly look to evolve and
develop their packaging.

**Recycled Paper Market**

**_Introduction_**

Paper can be produced using different types of fibers, either fresh virgin (wood) fibers or recycled paper. The

majority of recycled paper is collected from households and from the commercial and industrial industries, where
paper-based packaging accumulates. However, the amount of paper that can be recovered is largely dependent on
legislation that regulates who is allowed to collect and how paper is separated at the source. This has an impact on
production, as it is costly to sort mixed waste (paper) streams afterwards and comingling general waste and wastepaper
deteriorates fiber quality.

137


-----

Source: Company information.

_Market trends_

The growing focus on sustainability is boosting demand for recovered paper. As a result, cartonboard and

SB, made from recycled paper collected from municipal, commercial and industrial paper sources, are becoming
increasingly popular alternatives in many industries.

In 2022, within the European paper industry, the usage of paper for recycling was at approximately 49 million

tons, with an additional net volume of approximately 5 million tons (10% of the total 55 million tons) bought by
non-European countries. As discussed, the formerly high Chinese demand for European PfR has decreased to levels
close to zero. In 2022, the main export destinations of European PfR are India, Indonesia, Turkey and Vietnam. Other
countries, such as Malaysia and Thailand, have also increased imports of European PfR. As discussed, China is no
longer a main importer of European recycled paper. Within the EU, material differences exist among the major
European economies, with Germany, The Netherlands and Spain being net importers of both brown and white recycled
paper grades, while Italy and France are net exporters.

In 2023, demand softness was primarily driven by a customer de-stocking cycle after customers built up their

inventories during 2022 due to anticipated global supply chain disruptions after COVID-19. Other dynamics
influenced the paper industry such as substitution among grades and impact of the conflict in Ukraine, as well as
entering of new competitors in European market. As a result of the above trends, almost all paper producers in Europe
experienced reductions in revenues and volumes, which led to the implementation of price corrections.

Overall, in Europe, where paper collection is an advanced practice, collection rates for paper and boards are

already high (especially in industrial and retail). According to EUROSTAT, in between 2010 and 2021 the paper and
cartonboard recycling rate was close to 82.5%.

138


-----

Source: Company information.

Regulations are a key factor affecting the use of recycled paper. Collection is regulated at the European,

national and municipal levels. The European “Green Deal” package signed in 2019 and the evaluation of the “EU
Waste Shipment Regulation” (Regulation (EC) No 1418/2007), implemented in 2019 represent an action plan to boost
a clean circular economy, restore biodiversity and decrease pollution, which requires increasing waste collection and
recycling. With this aim, different levels of restrictions for the import and export of waste are under consideration and
countries are taking actions to introduce bans on waste imports and tighter regulation concerning waste quality and
contamination.

More specifically, the “Waste Framework Directive” (Directive 2018/851), establishes the following priority

order for managing waste: (i) waste prevention, (ii) reuse, (iii) recycling and (iv) other forms of recovery and disposal,
setting specific targets for the EU member states. According to the directive, the re-use and recycling of municipal
waste shall be increased to a minimum of 55%, 60% and 65% by 2025, 2030 and 2035 respectively. Moreover, the
“Packaging and Packaging Waste Directive” (Directive 2018/852/EC) sets out measures and requirements for the
prevention, re-use and recovery of packaging waste within the Member States.

Source: Company information, RISI.

**BUSINESS**

**Overview**

We are a leading European producer and distributor of recycled cartonboard, active in the coated and

uncoated recycled cartonboard industry. We operate in the WLC and solidboard SB market segments, in each case
with a demonstrated track record of making our operations more sustainable as both WLC and SB are manufactured
from recovered paper and we actively invest in our operations to reduce emissions, waste, water usage and other
environmental factors. Our cartonboard can be used as both primary and secondary packaging. Our WLC products
are predominantly used, without limitation, in packaging for the food, hygiene and cleaning, pharmaceuticals and
healthcare, electronics, textile and toy industries. Our SB products are mostly used for the packaging of luxury goods,
publishing applications (bookbinding), as well as for graphical applications, such as for puzzles and games.

Our identity is built on a clear vision centered on the circular economy that guides our activities as a

manufacturer of WLC and SB from recycled materials, and that represents a balanced combination between our
business and the expectations of our stakeholders; see also “—Our Production Process—Circular Business Model.”
Our ambition is to be the partner of choice of all key stakeholders with three strategic goals in mind: to offer excellent
products and services, to optimize costs and to maximize the satisfaction of our customers, all while helping drive
increased sustainability within the paper and packaging industry.

As of December 31, 2023, we served our customers through a network of ten mills (including Blendecques),

four sheeting and distribution centers, and 13 sales offices. As of December 31, 2023, we employed over 2,520
employees.

We believe that our geographical footprint across Europe and exposure to resilient end-markets (such as the

food end-market) are key strengths of our business, which we have reinforced through the recent Fiskeby Acquisition
in 2023 (in addition to Eska and Paprinsa Acquisitions in 2021). Our position as a leader in the European WLC market
is supported by our distributed network of mills, our “multi-mill” concept, whereby we seek to be able to offer similar
cartonboard products at different mills whenever possible, helping us meet our customers’ demands quickly regardless
of their proximity to a specific production site, and guarantee security of supply to our entire customer base. Our
distributed mill network is integrated by our “One Company” operating model, which helps to ensure we have both a
local presence near our customers and a platform with the scale and sophistication required to efficiently respond to
our customers’ needs across the continent.

to implement technological development initiatives to pursue our lean manufacturing philosophy, including through
new analytic initiatives to enhance quality integration, procurement, pricing and supply chain savings.

**_Our products and customers_**

We manufacture different types of recycled paperboard, sold as sheets or rolls, mainly to packaging

manufacturers. The majority of our sales derive from resilient and essential end-markets, such as the food end-market.

For the twelve months ended December 31, 2023 (after giving pro forma effect to the Fiskeby Acquisition),

more than 59% of the end-users of our WLC products operated within the resilient food market. Our SB products are

141


-----

purchased for use in applications such as producing packaging for the growing luxury packaging market, as well as
bookbinding, stationary, and manufacturing puzzles and games.

We are committed to sustainability and believe that are well-placed to benefit from the ongoing shift away

from plastic packaging and toward more sustainable alternatives. We believe that we have an attractive sustainability
profile, and our commitment to sustainability has been historically supported by a track record of demonstrable
achievements. For the year ended December 31, 2023 (after giving _pro forma_ effect to the Fiskeby Acquisition),
approximately 95% of the fibrous material we used was recycled and over 84% of all materials used consisted of
renewable materials. In addition, we have reduced our water discharges per ton of cartonboard produced by
approximately 15% since 2021.

As our business continues to evolve, we remain committed to strengthening our product portfolio and

offerings by focusing on renewable, recyclable and actually-recycled solutions (solutions with high recycling rates).
In line with the latest market trends, we are directing our development activities toward cartonboard and SB products
that can replace plastic packaging and are safe to be used for food product. We are focusing our efforts toward the
development of renewable and recyclable “barrier solutions” that are fully integrated with the fiber-based material
structure of the cartonboard. Our consistent aim is to promote and preserve the integrity of the packaged product while
ensuring recyclability of the coated and uncoated cartonboard after its use. In particular, the key themes of our product
innovation are (i) plastic to paper, with a focus on safety for food applications and barriers for grease, water and
oxygen; (ii) digitalization experience by delivering WLC and SB designed for e-commerce; (iii) environmental
experience with a continued focus on alternative sources for fibers and (iv) premium experience by delivering
premium materials and bi-colors board.

We are also currently developing a portfolio of new sustainable solutions to be rolled-out between 2025 and

2028, which we expect will increase our production volumes by more than 300 thousand tons per year. We are
committed to increase transparency in sustainability. To achieve this goal, we are pursuing the external validation of
the carbon footprint of our products and undergoing a third-party life cycle assessment. These activities will allow us
to evaluate sustainability claims and prioritize product initiatives with higher sustainability score.

(after giving pro forma effect to the Fiskeby Acquisition and including Blendecques), we have the largest production

As a leading WLC manufacturer, we are in the position to benefit from the growth and evolution of the WLC

market. Industry sources indicate that the WLC market segment is resilient and diversified. Just as the demand for
WLC ultimately depends on the demand from the end markets, the resilience of the WLC industry is also supported
by the diversity and by the resilience of the industry’s end markets.

The chart below is based on analysis from a global management consulting company and highlights how the

WLC demand is driven by the stable and resilient food end-market. Food end-market demand is defined by different
sub-segments, such as frozen and chilled food (19% of total demand), driven by demographic changes and
convenience trends, dry food (16% of total demand) and other food sub-segments (12% of total demand). Overall the
broad food end-market represents approximately 38% of the total demand for WLC.

We believe a number of market trends will continue to support WLC market development in Europe over the

next several years – with Southern Europe expected to experience even stronger demand growth as a consequence of
WLC’s stronger position in the region – and we believe we are well-positioned to benefit from these trends.

In particular, we believe there is a positive outlook for WLC over the next five years, as plastics replacement

trials start to move through to larger scale rollout. According to RDM Group’s analysis based on data provided by a
global management consulting company, there will be an additional market demand for 900 thousand tons of WLC
products between 2023 and 2028 (of which 160 thousand tons are expected by the end of 2024) due to plastic

143


-----

replacement opportunities. Primarily, these opportunities are present in the food and homecare sectors due to
cartonboard’s strength and barrier properties, which make it a suitable substitution for fruit punnets, confectionery
secondary packaging and dishwasher tablets or dilutables. To a lesser extent, there are additional opportunities in the
beverage, cosmetics and pharma sectors as the cartonboard’s structural integrity, premium finish together with its
other properties make it a good fit to drink multipacks, secondary packaging for cosmetic tubs and tubes or primary
packaging for multivitamins. We also believe that the growing preference for sustainable products, along with
increasing regulatory actions against the use of plastics and plastic packaging, will likely lead a growing number of
manufacturers to switch from plastic packaging to more sustainable alternatives, such as the WLC packaging made
from recycled fibers that we produce.

Additionally, we expect that e-commerce growth will drive demand for WLC liners used in packaging

production. We expect that demographic shifts and changes in consumer preferences favoring convenience will
increase the demand for frozen and convenience foods, and these segments of the food end-market are especially
heavy users of WLC packaging.

**_Pan-European, strategic asset base close to customers providing significant competitive advantages._**

We operate in accordance with our “multi-mill” and “multi-country” approaches, which we believe provide

us with significant competitive advantages in our sector, particularly given the highly localized nature of our customers
and the industry. Our multi mill concept represents one of our core operating principles. We aim to produce our
products in multiple mills whenever possible to ensure that our products are available to our customers in a flexible
and punctual manner and in close proximity to their production sites. We believe that the multi mill concept allows us
to adapt efficiently to changes in market demand and the economic cycles of the countries in which we operate. We
believe we have a well invested asset base, in terms of capacity, technical age, speed and trim compared to our industry
peers, which enables us to effectively pursue our “multi-mill” concept. As of December 31, 2023, we served our
customers through a network of ten mills (including Blendecques), four sheeting and distribution centers, and 13 sales
offices. Our mills are located in Italy, Spain, The Netherlands, Germany, France and Sweden, giving us a pan European
and strategic asset base close to our customers. As further discussed under “Summary—Recent Developments—
_Closure of the Blendecques mill,” we are currently planning to cease operations at the mill located in Blendecques,_
France, by the second half of 2024. Rather than managing each single mill to produce a single product, our mills are
designed, and operate, to manufacture multiple products whenever possible. As a result, we can shift production of
many of our products across our network of mills, which gives us flexibility to balance the availability of products at
individual plants and to integrate production planning across our mills. We also believe that our multi-mill concept
reinforces the benefits that we derive from our multi-country asset base. By increasing the interchangeability of our
mills and the specific types of our cartonboard produced in multiple mills, we also increase our ability to meet our
customers’ needs at each local plant. This allows us to reduce the time and cost required for product delivery and to
be more immediately responsive to customers’ needs and changing demands, providing meaningful upside in a market
characterized by localized preferences and requirements. Our focus on coordination within our multi-mill network
also allows us to monitor and better respond to market volatility arising from rapid changes in local demand or changes
in production at individual mills as well as from potential supply chain disruptions.

As part of the integration of the Fiskeby business following the Fiskeby Acquisition, we have successfully

applied our multi-mill concept to the Swedish plant. We believe that the multi-mill concept and post-acquisition
integration will allow us to transfer production volumes to different locations to reduce delivery times for existing
customers as well as to find new and more profitable markets and volumes.

**_We have historically demonstrated the ability to navigate in volatile environment delivering strong_**

**_financial performance._**

Starting from 2021 and 2022, as part of an industry-wide unprecedented and temporary phenomenon

affecting our entire value chain, we have experienced significant stocking and de-stocking dynamics, which resulted
in a divergence of patterns between consumption by our customers, on the one hand, and supply dynamics in our
product end-markets, on the other hand.

In particular, in 2021 and the first half of 2022, we experienced increased stocking by many of our customers,

which was primarily driven by their need to secure higher levels of inventories to meet expected market demand and
address supply chain uncertainty caused by macroeconomic concerns, such as supply chain disruptions related to
COVID-19 and other factors and heightened international tensions due to the conflict in Ukraine. Conversely, starting
in the second half of 2022, we experienced a decrease in the sale of our products, primarily as a result of the reduction
in purchase volumes by some of our customers who implemented de-stocking policies. Such customers started
reviewing their inventory management policies and decreased the level of our products held in stock as they prepared
for a generally improved macroeconomic environment in 2023 and as a result of a decrease in sales of their products
in certain end-markets, which was driven by several macroeconomic factors, including a persisting inflationary
environment, a material increases in global interest rates and general softness of private consumption with endcustomers showing recessionary behaviors.

We believe the de-stocking trend has now ended, as the stock of WLC in the European market is currently

very low as illustrated by the below chart from the European association representing the paper industry, CEPI.

This is also supported by the strong uptick in order intakes that the WLC European market is currently

experiencing, as illustrated by the below chart (source: CEPI), which clearly indicates that the demand is picking up.

148


-----

The decline in demand was coupled with a reduction in input costs, including the price of wastepaper starting

from the third quarter of 2022 and a normalization of energy costs starting from fourth quarter 2022. While the lower
demand and lower raw material prices generated some pressure on selling prices and we have slightly revised our
selling prices downward, we have managed to do that at a slower pace compared to our competitors due to our capacity
management and volume placement.

Importantly, due to our leading market position and size, we have been very disciplined on pricing and able

to retain more of the increase in our selling prices that we achieved over 2021 and 2022 versus the reduction in input
costs seen over the last year, allowing us to stabilize our contribution margin around €320 per ton over 2023. As
illustrated by the below chart, our current level of profitability is much higher compared that what we have been able
to achieve historically. We expect this level of contribution margin per ton to be sustainable. Additionally, we did not
sacrifice material market share to achieve this result.

**_We play a central role in the sustainable paper circular economy and have developed a record of_**

**_successfully executing our sustainability initiatives. We aim to continue to be a leader in this field and achieve our_**
**_well-identified long-term sustainability goals._**

As a manufacturer of WLC and SB from recycled materials, we view ourselves as playing a key role in

maintaining a sustainable circular economy. The primary raw material used in our manufacturing process is PfR and
paperboard obtained from municipal paper collection and commercial or industrial sources. We believe we are the
keystone “link” in the circular economy: we dissolve, treat and form wastepaper into recycled cartonboard, giving it
new life and use. Our WLC products are mainly sold to customers in the converting industry, who manufacture
packaging using the WLC we provide, while our SB products are sold to customers in industries such as printing and
bookbinding as well as to converters for use in packaging. After passing through the end-user, these materials can be
recycled and resupplied to us as raw materials for use in the manufacturing of new WLC or SB.

All of our products are fully recyclable, enabling them to be converted to packaging at a later stage.

Furthermore, for the year ended December 30, 2023, approximately 95% of the fibrous materials we used came from
recycled materials and over 84% of all materials used consisted of renewable materials, enabling us to foster the
circular economy.

In addition in 2022, we implemented strategic initiatives for the management and improvement of the quality

of the water used in the production from the mills of Hoogezand, Santa Giustina and Barcelona, that allow us to recycle

152


-----

the process water. In 2023, we invested in the development of the Ovaro power plant. These successful initiatives
further improved our water efficiency and contributed to strong operational performance. We have also started
building a new CHP plant in Barcelona to further reduce our GHG Emissions and achieve cost savings, which we
expect will be completed in the end of the second quarter of 2024.

**Business Strategy**

**_Further strengthen our positioning in the WLC market and expansion in the SB market._**

Through the Eska Acquisition and Paprinsa Acquisition, we have acquired three additional production sites,

expanded our SB product offerings, solidified our market leadership on the Iberian Peninsula, and broadened the
geographic footprint of our network of mills into The Netherlands and distribution centers into the United States.
Furthermore, with the Fiskeby acquisition we have grown our market share in the recycled board market, broadened
the geographic footprint of our network of mills into Sweden and became the largest independent recycled board
producer in Europe. The Fiskeby Acquisition provided us with the opportunity to further diversify and consolidate
our position in Northern and Central Europe, enhancing our multi-mill approach, strengthening our ESG profile, while
improving the overall quality of our offering and granting us direct access to brand owners providing volumes visibility
and opportunities to accelerate plastic substitution.

**_Actively integrate our recent acquisitions to extract commercial and cost synergies and operate with a_**

**_culture of continuous improvement to perpetually strengthen our operating efficiencies and streamline our cost_**
**_structure._**

We have identified several synergy opportunities that we are actively pursuing as the process of integrating

Fiskeby progresses. We have also identified various cost savings initiatives that we conservatively believe will provide
us with potential annual gross cost savings of over €36.6 million in aggregate by the end of 2028 (noting that we have
identified additional areas of upside for further cost savings). These initiatives include (but are not limited to):

    - **_Plant initiatives:_** plant-level operational efficiencies from machinery upgrades / new equipment to
decrease variable costs (e.g., waste, which we believe could yield gross cost savings of approximately
€12.8 million per year once fully implemented);

    - **_Energy opportunities: investment in new co-generation plant and other equipment to reduce energy costs_**
(which we believe could yield gross cost savings of approximately €14.7 million per year once fully
implemented);

    - **_“ExcellenceOne” Program: a program composed of several initiatives such as lean manufacturing_**
philosophy roll-out, process analytics, maintenance, quality integration, procurement / pricing and
supply chain saving through digitalization (which we believe could yield gross cost savings of
approximately €1.2 million per year once fully implemented); and

154


-----

    - **_Fiskeby Integration: alignment of the performance of the overall equipment effectiveness to the Group_**
one, together with price repositioning, cross selling potential and procurement synergies (which we
believe could yield additional EBITDA impact of €8.0 million).

**_Leverage Fiskeby attractive product offering to expand geographical reach and increase customer base_**

We believe that the Fiskeby acquisition has been highly strategic and will provide us with the opportunity to

(i) grow our market share in the recycled board market and become the largest independent non-integrated recycled
board producer in Europe, (ii) enhance the security of our supply, (iii) expand in attractive markets such as the United
Kingdom, Baltics, Nordics and Poland, (iv) serve pan-European customers in a multi-mill reinforced approach, (v)
improve our cost structure with Fiskeby’s waste-to-energy plant that shelters the mill from any volatility moves in the
energy markets, (vi) use the higher technical performance of Fiskeby’s boards to compete with producers of virgin
fiber cartonboards, and (ix) reduce our carbon footprint, as the Fiskeby’s mill uses alternative sources of energy.

**_Continue implementing our digitalization agenda to strengthen our “One Company” culture and_**

**_multi-mill concept._**

We believe our multi-mill concept and “One Company” culture provide us with tangible competitive

advantages, and we plan to scale up the impact of these key strengths by further implementing our digitalization
agenda. In addition, we believe our digitalization agenda will allow us to further develop and integrate our multi-mill
concept in our SB sector following the Eska Acquisition in order to continuously improve and enhance our product
offerings, competitive advantages and interchangeability with products produced in the various SB mills.

Our digitalization agenda is a comprehensive digital transformation program aimed at achieving efficiencies

through all areas of the Group, including projects on operations, logistics, procurement, human resources, sales,
planning and health and safety. As such, we strive to further expand and improve our product and service offerings,
as well as our manufacturing and service processes. We view digital improvement as a key strategy to improve our
efficiency, innovation and coordination across our operations.

Through sophisticated digital applications, we are focused on continuing to deliver high-quality and

innovative products across the entire value chain and circular economy in which we operate, with a clear strategy of
continuously strengthening our operational efficiency and excellence through lean manufacturing plans and initiatives.

**_Continue developing new, innovative products to answer the needs of our customers_**

We believe that product innovation is a key pillar of our strategy and we are focused on further improving

our product offering in order to answer the needs of our clients, be on top of secular trends and capitalize on new
opportunities and unlock additional growth. In this respect, we have identified certain strategic themes which are the
key focus areas of our product innovation:

    - _Plastic to paper substitution: working on greater usage of papers for food applications and barriers for_
grease, water and oxygen;

    - _Digitalization experience: working on WLC and SB designed for e-commerce;_

    - _Environmental: working on alternative sources for fibers; and_

    - _Premium: working on creation of bi-color boards and premium materials._

**_Maintain our sustainability leadership and our focus on achieving our long-term sustainability goals._**

Sustainability is central to our business model and our management team. We are proud of our role in the

circular economy and our ability to grow the sustainability of our business alongside financial performance. To
continue to drive this forward, we have identified clear, quantifiable long-term sustainability goals for 2025 and 2030.
These goals include the following:

    - _Climate Change: By 2030, our goal is to have reduced GHG Emissions by 30% (emissions in 2020_
equaled 0.495 tCO2 emissions per ton);

    - _Waste Reduction and Recovery: By 2030, our goal is to have reduced the total amount of waste generated_
per ton of net saleable product by 18% (total waste per ton of net saleable product in 2020 was
181 kilograms per ton) and have increased the proportion of waste sent for recovery to 90% (proportion
of waste recovered in 2020 was 73%);

    - _Water: By 2030, our goal is to have reduced wastewater discharge per ton of net saleable product by_
20% (wastewater discharge per ton of net saleable product in 2020 was 11.06 cubic meters per ton);

    - _Employee Wellbeing:_ By 2030, our goal is to have increased the employee advocacy rate to 4.5 (the

    - _Diversity: By 2030, our goal is to have increased the percentage of female employees by 30% (in 2020,_

    - _Responsible Sourcing of Materials: By 2025, our goal is to have implemented a new program to assess_
and qualify all of our key suppliers for all relevant product categories according to ESG criteria.

Additionally, this Offering is sustainability-linked, with a Sustainability-Linked Financing Framework. Our

Sustainability-Linked Financing Framework includes Sustainability Performance Targets for the most material
indicators for our business for 2025. These are:

      - _Climate Change: By the end of 2025, our goal is to have reduced GHG Emissions by 15% (from_
the 2020 baseline of 0.495 tCO2e/ton);

      - Waste: By the end of 2025, our goal is to have increased the proportion of waste sent for recovery
to 86.2% (from the 2020 baseline of 72.8%); and

      - _Water: By the end of 2025, our goal is to have reduced wastewater discharge per ton of net saleable_
