#### COMMODITY RISK

The commodity risk mainly refers to the movements of the prices of the raw materials that are purchased for production and the
margins that are influenced by the possibility of reversing the trend of the prices of energy and raw materials on the prices of the
products sold. Most contractual relationships with customers involve a transfer of the price risk of the raw materials to the
customer. In order to mitigate the price risk where the transfer is not foreseen, the price lists with customers are reviewed on a
quarterly basis.

More in detail, the nature of the Group’s business involves exposure to fluctuations in the prices of electricity, natural gas and
certain chemical products derived from petroleum (such as latexes) and fibrous raw materials. Natural gas supply contracts are
usually agreed for total requirements at a fixed price and are negotiated at least three months before the supply period, but
sometimes for longer periods in relation to the supply period. Electricity is purchased partly at a fixed price, and partially indexed
according to the values of continental electricity markets as published by the bodies responsible for these markets. In order to
contain possible price pressure on raw materials, the Group aims to diversify its suppliers and its supply markets.

As of the date of the statement of financial position there are no derivative instruments held to commodity risk.

#### INTEREST RATE RISK

Interest rate risk mainly refers to the Group’s exposure to changes in cash flows due to fluctuation in market interest rates, with
particular reference to the interest expense outflows paid on financial debt.

As of December 31, 2023, about 70% of the Group's financial debt is composed of the Sustainability-Linked Senior Secured Floating
Rate Notes which substantially bear interest cost at a rate equal to Euribor 3 months (with a 0% floor) plus 5.25% per annum, reset
quarterly, and about 20% of the Group's financial debt is composed of the Senior Facility Agreement which substantially bear
interest cost at a rate equal to Euribor 6 months (with a 0% floor) plus 3.00% per annum. The Deferred Price related to Fiskeby
Group acquisition, amounting to €8,7 million as of December 31, 2023 and about 1% of the Group's financial debt, follows the same
rate rules of the Sustainability-Linked Senior Secured Floating Rate Notes.

With the acquisition of Fiskeby, the Group has acquired a credit line granted in SEK by Nordea Bank in Sweden for an amount of
€19.3 million as of December 31, 2023.

The Group remains exposed to residual interest rate risk for the bank loans that are held for which the uncovered variable rate
financial debt represents an element of risk of impact that could occur on the income statement and on cash flows as a result of an
increase in market interest rates.

The main exposure to interest rate risk derives from the Sustainability-Linked Senior Secured Floating Rate Notes and from the
Senior Facility Agreement. With reference to the Sustainability-Linked Senior Secured Floating Rate Notes, the Group in 2023 has
decided to hedge the financial liability to mitigate this exposure by the subscription of a Rate Collar that covers a notional amount
of €220 million (out of a total nominal amount of €445 million); the instrument has a cap rate of 3.972%, a floor rate of 2.68%, and
is effective from December 15, 2023 to December 15, 2025. With reference to the Senior Facility Agreement the group has decided
not to hedge the financial liability to mitigate this exposure.

An increase or reduction of 25 basis points in Euribor rates would result in an increase/decrease of finance expense of €871
thousand in 2024 and €1.9 million over the residual maturity of the Notes.

The Notes also include a step-up feature: from June 15, 2026 the interest rate will increase by 0.5%, 1.0% or 1.5% depending on
whether respectively, one, two or three of the Sustainability Performance Targets defined in the Offering Memorandum are not
achieved. Considering the actions put in place by the management and the potential change in the perimeter of the Group
companies included in the valuation of the targets, as a result of M&A transactions either already realized and forecasted, the
management does not see any critical element that could impair the ability of the Group to achieve all three targets by 2025. The
company has therefore not revised its estimate of payments and accordingly not included the step-up feature in the amortized cost
of the Notes.

###### IBOR REFORM

A fundamental reform of major interest rate benchmarks is being undertaken globally, including the replacement of some interbank
offered rates (IBORs) with alternative nearly risk‑free rates (referred to as ‘IBOR reform’).

With respect to the Euro Interbank Offered Rate – Euribor, during 2019 the calculation methodology changed and in July 2019 the
European Money Markets Institute was granted authorization for administration of Euribor under the European Union Benchmarks
Regulation by the Belgian Financial Services and Markets Authority. The European Securities and Markets Authority (ESMA)
substituted the Belgian FSMA on January 1, 2022.

This allows market participants to continue to use Euribor for both existing and new contracts. The Group expects that Euribor will
continue to exist as a benchmark rate for the foreseeable future.

###### CREDIT RISK

Credit risk is essentially derived from receivables from customers. The Group’s exposure to credit risk is influenced mainly by the
individual characteristics of each customer. However, management also considers the factors that may influence the credit risk of
its customer base, including the default risk associated with the industry and country in which customers operate.

To mitigate the credit risk related to commercial counterparties, and therefore domestic and foreign customers, the Group's
operating companies have put in place procedures aimed at ensuring that product sales are made to customers who are deemed
reliable according to the Group’s standard payment and delivery conditions.

This risk, which takes the form of the possibility that the counterparty does not fulfill its contractual obligations, is mitigated through
constant monitoring of each Group company’s commercial exposure and the collection times of receivables.

The amount of financial assets considered of doubtful recoverability is not significant; in any case it is covered by appropriate
allocations to the provision for doubtful receivables. See Note 19 for more details about the provision for doubtful receivables.

###### CAPITAL RISK

###### FAIR VALUE ESTIMATE

The fair value of financial instruments listed on an active market is based on market prices as of the statement of financial position
date.

The fair value of instruments that are not listed on an active market is determined using valuation techniques based on a series of
methods and assumptions related to market conditions at the statement of financial position date, including: current or recent
quoted prices for identical instruments in markets that are not active; or, a net present value calculated using discount rates derived
from quoted yields of instruments with similar maturity and credit rating that are traded in active markets, adjusted by an illiquidity
factor.

As of December 31, 2023 the Sustainability-Linked Senior Secured Notes have a carrying amount at amortized cost of €436.1 million;
their last market price quoted on Euro MTF on December 18, 2023 was 100.250%, therefore its fair value (measured as a level 1
fair value) as of December 31, 2023 is €446.1 million.

The fair values of the remaining borrowings are not materially different from their carrying amounts, since the interest payable on
those borrowings is aligned to current market rates and the spread applied to Euribor reflects the credit risk of the Group entities.

Disclosures of fair value are not required for lease liabilities, in accordance with IFRS 7 paragraph 29.

The IRS and FX forward instruments have been acquired with the integration of Fiskeby group, starting from July 1, 2023, while the
rate collar has been subscribed in December 2023.

An explanation for each level included in the table is listed below:

Level 1: The fair value of financial instruments traded in active markets (e.g. publicly traded derivatives and debt securities) is based
on quoted market prices at the end of the reporting period. The quoted market price incorporates the market's assumptions with
respect to changes in economic climate such as rising interest rates and inflation, as well as changes due to ESG risk. These
instruments are included in level 1.

Level 2: The fair value of financial instruments that are not traded in an active market (e.g. over the counter derivatives) is
determined using valuation techniques which maximise the use of observable market data and rely as little as possible on entityspecific estimates. If all significant inputs required to fair value an instrument are observable, the instrument is included in level 2.

Level 3: If one or more of the significant inputs is not based on observable market data, the instrument is included in level 3. This is
the case for unlisted equity securities and for instruments where credit risk gives rise to a significant unobservable valuation
component.

VALUATION TECHNIQUES AND INPUTS USED TO DETERMINE FAIR VALUES

Specific valuation techniques used to value financial instruments may include:

  - the use of quoted market prices or dealer quotes for similar instruments;

  - for interest rate swaps: the present value of the estimated future cash flows based on observable yield curves;

  - for foreign currency forwards: the present value of future cash flows based on the forward exchange rates at the reporting
date;

  - for other financial instruments: discounted cash flow analysis.

All of the resulting fair value estimates are included in level 2, as they rely in particular on unobservable credit risk components of
the issuer of the instruments. The fair value of derivative financial instruments has been derived from the mark-to-market valuations
provided by the counterparty banks.

FAIR VALUES OF OTHER FINANCIAL INSTRUMENTS (UNRECOGNISED)

The Group also has a number of financial instruments which are not measured at fair value in the statement of financial position.
For the majority of these instruments, including trade receivables and payables, bank loans and other borrowings, the fair values
are not materially different to their carrying amounts, since the interest receivable/payable is either close to current market rates
and the spread applied reflects the credit risk of the counterparties, or the instruments are short-term in nature.

As of December 31, 2023 the Senior Secured Sustainability-linked Notes have a carrying amount at amortized cost of €436.1 million;
their last market price quoted on Euro MTF on December 18, 2023 was 100.250%, therefore their fair value (measured as a level 1
fair value) as of December 31, 2023 is €446.1 million. This is the most significant difference between the carrying amount and the
fair value of financial instruments not measured at fair value in the statement of financial position.

# 4. BUSINESS COMBINATION

###### Acquisition of Fiskeby International Holding AB

As reported in the paragraph 1.1 - Significant events during the period, the Group signed the agreement for the acquisition of Fiskeby
International Holding AB on July 13, 2023.

The transaction price included an upfront component of €127.5 million, of which €125.3 million were paid to the seller and €2.2
million were paid to the management of the company as bonuses. The transaction price also included two deferred payments of
€4.3 million (due on March 31, 2024) and €4.3 million (due on March 31, 2025). The total investment amounted therefore to €136.2
million.

As a result of this transaction, Reno de Medici S.p.A. controls Fiskeby International Holding AB with a 100% stake. The acquisition
date has been conventionally set at July 1[st], 2023. The entities included in the Fiskeby sub-group are:

The Group’s business activities are not organised on the basis of differences in products and services or on differences in
geographical areas of operations, since reportable revenues derive essentially from the same product, i.e. recycled cartonboard.
Even if the Group hold assets in different geographical areas, customers are served from different mills in different countries,
according to the “Multi-mill concept”.

Therefore, the Group has determined that it has only one reportable segment (“Recycled Board”) based on the information
reviewed by its Chief Operating Decision Maker, defined as the Board of Directors of the Company, in making decisions regarding
allocation of resources and to assess performance.

# 6. REVENUES FROM SALES

More than 85% of the Group's revenues relate to sales with customers in Italy and Europe and the remaining revenues are generated
through sales to customers from the rest of the world. For additional details on revenues breakdown, please refer to the
Management Report.

Revenues from sales amounted to €798.4 million, compared to €1,222.3 million of the previous period.

As of December 31, 2023 the decrease was primarily attributable to the contraction of market demand. The decrease of market
demand affected the entire market and is due to a general weak demand and prices reduction as consequence of inflation
downward path since the beginning of the year.

The 2022 revenues have been characterized by increases in sales prices partially offset by decreases in volumes due to the
Blendecques and Villa Santa Lucia mills production shutdown. These shutdowns are respectively due to a fire occurred at
Blendecques mill in March 2022 and to the stop of the external water treatment plant at Villa Santa Lucia mill, due to causes not
under control of Reno De Medici.

Taxes decreased by €26.7 million, to a revenue of €3.9 million for the year ended December 31, 2023 compared to a cost amount
of €22.8 million for the year ended December 31, 2022. The benefit is mainly related to positive taxation in Reno De Medici S.p.A.
and includes the benefit from the possibility to utilize tax losses carried forward of Rimini BidCo S.p.A. which were not ded ucted in
previous years, for a positive impact of €7.4 million on 2023 taxes.

On May 23, 2023 IASB emitted the document Amendments to IAS 12 Income Taxes: International Tax Reform – Pillar Two Model
Rules:

On January 1, 2024 came into effect the new Pillar 2 rules, required by UE directive n. 2523 of December 14, 2022, adopted in Italy
with “D.lgs. n. 209” of December 27, 2023 (“Decreto”), implementing the new reform about international taxation. These rules are
applied in TopCo Group as a Multinational Group that exceed the threshold of €750 million of revenues for two of the four previous
fiscal years and having as Ultimate Parent Entity (UPE) Rimini TopCo S.p.A.

On the base of Pillar 2 rules, the entities included in the group perimeter (localized everywhere) must be subject of a level of
effective taxation on income at least of 15%, to be determined on the base of an articulated counting built on accounting and fiscal


-----

**Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements**

**As of and for the year ended December 31, 2023 and as of and for the year ended December 31, 2022 (continued)**

data. In the case in which these entities are subject to a level of taxation lower than 15%, it will be applied a minimum tax (Top-Up
Tax) that will lead the level of effective taxation to 15%.

The exposition to income taxes of Pillar 2 depends, relating to all group companies (and the eventual join-ventures entities) that
are located in every single jurisdiction, from the level of effective taxation that, for every single jurisdiction, depends from various
factors, interconnected between them, mainly the income produced, the level of nominal rate, the fiscal rules for the determination
of tax base, the forecast, the form and the utilization of incentives and other fiscal benefits.

Furthermore, considering the new law and the complexity under the determination of the level of effective taxation, the legislation
of Pillar 2 implies, for the first periods of effectiveness (transitory regime valid for the periods that start before December 31, 2026
and expire no later than June 6, 2028), the possibility to apply a simplified regime (Transitional Safe Harbours country by country),
mainly based on accounting information available for every relevant jurisdiction that, in case of passing at least one of the three
tests, implies the reduction of losses and the elimination of Pillar 2 taxes.

In accordance with the disclosure requirements of IAS 12, the Rimini TopCo Group made an analysis in order to identify the
application perimeter of Pillar 2 rules, as well as the potential impacts that derive from the application of the law in the different
Countries in which it operates, taking into account the mentioned Transitional Safe Harbours.

Therefore, after the identification of all the in-scope entities of the Group for the discipline, aligned with what reported by the
“Decreto” and with the OCSE guidelines, the Rimini TopCo Group adopted the “Transitional Safe Harbours” (“TSH”), in relation with
every Country in which it operates.

In relation with the Countries in which any TSH test have been passed, the Rimini TopCo Group will be obliged to perform a
calculation of the level of effective taxation based on the entire set of rules of Pillar 2 reported by the “Decreto” adding in this
manner, to the accounting and fiscal data of the entities localized in these Countries, the adjustments provided by that law, also
with the aim to determine, where the level of effective taxation is lower than 15%, the value of the minimum tax.

On base of the analysis performed, with respect of Pillar 2, the entity Rimini TopCo S.p.A. is qualified as “Ultimate Parent Entity” or
“UPE”.

The application of TSH has been conducted on the basis of the information available in the Country-by-Country Report, prepared
by the UPE for 2022 Fiscal Year, considering the “aggregated data” of the entities part of Rimini TopCo Group for every Country in
which it operates (“Jurisdictional Approach”).

It should be noted that the analysis have been performed also taking into consideration some points that are still under examination
and not clarified by OCSE.

On the basis of that analysis, the THS results are positive on almost all the entities of Rimini TopCo Group and, in any case, it is
assumed that, according to the assessments performed until now, the combined application of THS and Pillar 2 rules don’t
determine, in 2024 Fiscal Year, a significant exposition to Top-Up Tax for Rimini TopCo Group.

The considerations mentioned above are based on a forward-looking evaluation of fiscal charge, determined considering the data
and the information available in this moment and on the basis of a simplified approach. An accurate estimate of fiscal charge for
jurisdiction will be possible only once the data of 2024 Fiscal Year will be available.

In the end, it should be pointed out that, in accordance with IAS 12, the entity doesn’t have detected any effect on deferred taxation
coming from the entry in force of the Pillar 2 rules from January 1, 2024.

# 13. GOODWILL

The item “Goodwill” amounts to € 243.7 million (€ 132.1 million on December 31, 2022). The increase is related to the provisi onal
goodwill allocated on the TopCo Group on December 31, 2023 for the Fiskeby’s acquisition. For more information, see paragraph
_Business Acquisition._


-----

**Notes to Consolidated Financial Statements**

**As of and for the year ended December 31, 2023 and as of and for the year ended December 31, 2022 (continued)**

Goodwill resulting from the acquisition of Reno De Medici Group by Rimini TopCo S.p.A. (the “TopCo goodwill”) has been allocated
to one cash-generating unit (“CGU”) identified as the Reno De Medici Group itself (excluding Fiskeby); while the new provisional
goodwill deriving from the acquisition of Fiskeby (the “Fiskeby goodwill”) has been allocated to a separate CGU identified as the
Fiskeby sub-group.

For the purposes of preparing these Consolidated Financial Statements, the Company has ascertained that there are some indicators
that may suggest difficulties in recovering the book value of the TopCo goodwill, also considering the results achieved by the
business until December 31, 2023, and the surge in market interest rates during the year.

However, the TopCo goodwill has been tested for impairment according to IAS 36 as of December 31, 2023 and as a result no
reduction in value has been recorded.

For the 2023 reporting period, the recoverable amount of the cash-generating unit was determined based on value in use
calculations, which require the use of assumptions. The calculations use cash flow projections based on financial forecasts approved
by management covering a five-year period. Cash flows beyond the five-year period are extrapolated using the estimated long-term
growth rate of 2%, which is consistent with industry forecasts.

The projected cash flows have been discounted at a weighted average cost of capital (“WACC”) rate, in which the cost of equity is
calculated in accordance with the capital assets pricing model methodology and the cost of debt reflects the actual interest rates
paid by the Group.

The Fiskeby goodwill has not been tested for impairment since the process of purchase price allocation (the “PPA”) is still ongoing
as of December 31, 2023 and will be concluded in the first half 2024 according to IFRS 3.

in accordance with IAS 36.

The net book value of assets of Blendeques mill resulted aligned and justified from the assessment performed last year through an
opinion from a third party expert with evaluation method in line with principles and practices of the market. Since the assessment
resulted to be recent and used for the purchase price allocation performed in 2022, it was considered valid to use the same Fair
Value of the assets for the impairment test, less the amortization of the current fiscal year.

Furthermore, some assets have been reconstructed during fiscal year 2023 and the entity has evaluated that the costs of
reconstruction are in line with market prices. Also in this case have not been detected exceptions. Therefore, the fair value of assets
as above determined has been reduced by the anticipated amortization of the period and of the further costs to sell, engagement
and disinvestment.

###### Sustainability-Linked Senior Secured Floating Rate Notes 

In the context of the acquisition of RDM Group, Rimini BidCo S.p.A. (subsequently merged into RDM S.p.A.) issued Floating Rate
Sustainability-Linked Senior Secured Notes at a variable rate of three-month EURIBOR (with a 0% floor) plus 5.25% per annum, reset
quarterly, for an amount equal to € 445 million due December 14, 2026 (the “Notes”).

The redemption of the Notes is expected in full at the maturity date, while interest accrues on a quarterly basis with payments
scheduled on March 15, June 15, September 15 and December 15 of each year, commencing on March 15, 2022. The Notes were
offered for subscription to institutional investors and were listed on the Luxembourg stock exchange (EURO MTF Market). The
current portion of the Notes includes the interest coupon.

###### Super Senior Revolving Facilities

Rimini BidCo S.p.A. (subsequently merged into RDM S.p.A.) as original borrower and original guarantor, the lenders party thereto,
Barclays Bank PLC as agent and The Law Debenture Trust Corporation p.l.c. as security agent entered into a super senior revolving
facilities agreement (the “Revolving Credit Facility Agreement”) which provides for borrowings up to an aggregate principal amount
of €70.0 million on a committed basis substantially at Euribor (with a 0% floor) plus 3.50% per annum on drawn amounts. The
Revolving Credit Facility must be repaid in full on the maturity date in 2026. However, amounts repaid by the borrowers on loans
made under the Revolving Credit Facility may be re-borrowed during the availability period for that facility, subject to certain
exceptions.

###### Senior Facility Agreement

In the context of the acquisition of Fiskeby Holding AB, on July 11, 2023, a Senior Facility Agreement has been entered by Reno De
Medici S.p.A with a pool of banks in order to finance the acquisition. The term loan facility granted by the banks has a nominal
amount of €126 million and will mature on June 14, 2026 with a variable rate equal to the Euribor six-month (with a floor of 0%)
plus a spread of 3%. Against this loan, Reno De Medici S.p.A. paid an upfront fee for € 2.8 million.

Through its defined benefit pension plans, the Group is exposed to certain risks, the most significant of which are described below.

###### Discounting and inflation rate risk

The present value of defined benefit pension plans is calculated using a discount rate determined using high quality corporate bond
yields. A decrease in the discount rate would result in an increase in the liability. A decrease in the inflation rate would result in a
decrease in the liability.

###### Probability of resignations 

The present value of defined benefit pension plans is calculated using the best estimate of resignations. An increase in the rate of
resignations and advances would result in an increase in the liability.

capital of the Company (the "Shares"). Especially, the Rimini TopCo S.p.A. pledged Shares, as a guarantee of the covered obligations,
in favor of the following Guaranteed Creditors: BNP Paribas, Italian Branch, Barclays Bank PLC, Credit Suisse AG, Milan Branch, Intesa
Sanpaolo S.p.A. and UniCredit S.p.A. It should be noted that, on 13 January 2022, pursuant to the guarantee release agreement
"Global Deed of Release", unilaterally signed by BNP Paribas, the Italian Branch, the Agent for Guarantees accepted the full,
unconditional and irrevocable cancellation and release of the pledge concerning n. 50,000 shares of Rimini BidCo S.p.A.,
representing 100% of the share capital of Rimini BidCo S.p.A. originally registered in its favor and in favor of secured creditors.
Subsequently, on January 14, 2022, based on "Pledge Agreement over Rimini BidCo S.p.A. Shares" between The Law Debenture
Trust Corporation P.L.C. and Rimini TopCo S.p.A. which pledged the Shares, as collateral for the covered obligations in favor of the
following guaranteed creditors: The Law Debenture Trust Corporation P.L.C., Barclays Bank Ireland PLC, BNP Paribas, Italian Branch,
Credit Suisse AG, Milan Branch, Intesa Sanpaolo S.p.A., Unicredit S.p.A. and Barclays Bank PLC.

With reference to the above-mentioned "Pledge Agreement over Shares of Rimini BidCo S.p.A." subscribed on October 21, 2021,
by Rimini TopCo S.p.A. over the shares of Rimini BidCo S.p.A., it should be noted that, as a result of the reverse merger of Rimini
BidCo S.p.A. into Reno De Medici S.p.A., a confirmation and extension of the pledge agreement over the shares of Reno De Medici
S.p.A. (the Pledge Agreement) has been entered into on January 3, 2023 between Rimini TopCo S.p.A. (the Pledgor) and The Law
Debenture Trust Corporation P.L.C., in its name and as Security Agent and “mandatario con rappresentanza” of the other Secured
Parties (as defined in the Pledge Agreement). The Pledge over the shares of Rimini BidCo has been cancelled as a result of the
reverse merger and the absorption of Rimini BidCo S.p.A. by Reno De Medici S.p.A.

Pursuant to the above the Pledgor has confirmed and extended a pledge over no. 263,700,000 shares of Reno de Medici S.p.A. (the
Company) owned by the Pledgor, representing 99.2% of the share capital and 99.99% of the voting rights of the Company’s share
capital, in favor of the Secured Parties and their successors, assignees and transferees.

###### Subsequent events

In relation with the event that occurred at the Reno de Medici paper mill in Villa Santa Lucia, the Group has continued to pursue a
collaborative approach to resolve the situation and has carried out formal conversations with the administrative authorities to
renew the authorization and restart the mill. A satisfactory solution of the technically unresolved issues has been reached as of the
end of February 2024, and the mill will start on March 4, 2024. The pending technical issues still ongoing will be discussed with the
administrative authorities in the next weeks to obtain the renewal of the authorization with all matters agreed.

Our Blendecques mill was shut down since March 22, 2022 as a result of a fire that occurred due to causes outside our control, and
has been hit twice by flooding in November 2023 and January 2024, as described above. To mitigate the current overcapacity in our
European market and address the underperformance of the Blendecques mill, the Group is currently considering strategic
alternatives and currently intend to cease operations at the Blendecques mill in the second half of 2024. We believe the closure of
this mill will improve our profitability, optimize our industrial footprint and allow us to more efficiently adapt our curren t mill
capacity to changes in demand for cartonboard, capacity in the market as well as the resulting pricing pressures.

To the Shareholders of Rimini TopCo SpA


###### Report on the Audit of the Consolidated Financial Statements


**_Opinion_**

We have audited the consolidated financial statements of Rimini TopCo Group (the Group), which
comprise the consolidated statement of financial position as of 31 December 2022, the consolidated
income statement, consolidated statement of comprehensive income, statement of changes in
consolidated equity, consolidated statement of cash flows for the year then ended, and explanatory
notes to the consolidated financial statements, including a summary of significant accounting
policies.

In our opinion, the consolidated financial statements give a true and fair view of the financial position
of the Group as of 31 December 2022, and of the result of its operations and cash flows for the year
then ended in accordance with International Financial Reporting Standards as adopted by the
European Union.

**_Basis for Opinion_**

We conducted our audit in accordance with International Standards on Auditing (ISA Italia).
Our responsibilities under those standards are further described in the Auditor’s Responsibilities for
_the Audit of the Consolidated Financial Statements section of this report. We are independent of_
Rimini TopCo SpA (the Company) pursuant to the regulations and standards on ethics and
independence applicable to audits of financial statements under Italian law. We believe that the audit
evidence we have obtained is sufficient and appropriate to provide a basis for our opinion.

**_Responsibilities of the Directors and the Board of Statutory Auditors for the_**
**_Consolidated Financial Statements_**

The directors are responsible for the preparation of consolidated financial statements that give a true
and fair view in accordance with International Financial Reporting Standards as adopted by the
European Union and, in the terms prescribed by law, for such internal control as they determine is
necessary to enable the preparation of consolidated financial statements that are free from material
misstatement, whether due to fraud or error.


-----

The directors are responsible for assessing the Group’s ability to continue as a going concern and, in
preparing the consolidated financial statements, for the appropriate application of the going concern
basis of accounting, and for disclosing matters related to going concern. In preparing the consolidated
financial statements, the directors use the going concern basis of accounting unless they either intend
to liquidate Rimini TopCo SpA or to cease operations, or have no realistic alternative but to do so.

The board of statutory auditors is responsible for overseeing, in the terms prescribed by law, the
Group’s financial reporting process.

**_Auditor’s Responsibilities for the Audit of the Consolidated Financial Statements_**

Our objectives are to obtain reasonable assurance about whether the consolidated financial
statements as a whole are free from material misstatement, whether due to fraud or error, and to
issue an auditor’s report that includes our opinion. Reasonable assurance is a high level of assurance
but is not a guarantee that an audit conducted in accordance with International Standards on
Auditing (ISA Italia) will always detect a material misstatement when it exists. Misstatements can
arise from fraud or error and are considered material if, individually or in the aggregate, they could
reasonably be expected to influence the economic decisions of users taken on the basis of the
consolidated financial statements.

As part of our audit conducted in accordance with International Standards on Auditing (ISA Italia),
we exercised professional judgement and maintained professional scepticism throughout the audit.
Furthermore:

- We identified and assessed the risks of material misstatement of the consolidated financial
statements, whether due to fraud or error; we designed and performed audit procedures
responsive to those risks; we obtained audit evidence that is sufficient and appropriate to
provide a basis for our opinion. The risk of not detecting a material misstatement resulting
from fraud is higher than for one resulting from error, as fraud may involve collusion, forgery,
intentional omissions, misrepresentations, or the override of internal control;

- We obtained an understanding of internal control relevant to the audit in order to design
audit procedures that are appropriate in the circumstances, but not for the purpose of
expressing an opinion on the effectiveness of the Group’s internal control;

- We evaluated the appropriateness of accounting policies used and the reasonableness of
accounting estimates and related disclosures made by the directors;

- We concluded on the appropriateness of the directors’ use of the going concern basis of
accounting and, based on the audit evidence obtained, whether a material uncertainty exists
related to events or conditions that may cast significant doubt on the Group’s ability to
continue as a going concern. If we conclude that a material uncertainty exists, we are required
to draw attention in our auditor’s report to the related disclosures in the consolidated
financial statements or, if such disclosures are inadequate, to modify our opinion. Our
conclusions are based on the audit evidence obtained up to the date of our auditor’s report.
However, future events or conditions may cause the Group to cease to continue as a going
concern;

- We evaluated the overall presentation, structure and content of the consolidated financial
statements, including the disclosures, and whether the consolidated financial statements
represent the underlying transactions and events in a manner that achieves fair presentation;

- We obtained sufficient appropriate audit evidence regarding the financial information of the
entities or business activities within the Group to express an opinion on the consolidated
financial statements. We are responsible for the direction, supervision and performance of
the group audit. We remain solely responsible for our audit opinion on the consolidated
financial statements.


-----

# 1. GENERAL INFORMATION

Rimini TopCo S.p.A. (hereinafter "Rimini TopCo", the "Company" or the "Parent Company") is a company established
on June 14, 2021 and domiciled in Italy, with registered office in Milan, in Via Alessandro Manzoni, 38 and organized
according to the legal system of the Italian Republic.

The subscribed and paid up share capital of Rimini TopCo amounts to €3,045 thousand, divided into 304,525,482 shares
without nominal value and, in particular, into (i) 4,550,000 class “A” shares, (ii) 355,004 class “B” shares and (iii)
299,620,478 class “C” shares. The term of the Company is fixed until 31 December 2050. The Company’s ultimate
controlling entity is AGM Management, LLC, a limited company incorporated under the laws of the State of Delaware
(USA).

It should be noted that in October 2021 the Company acquired the Reno De Medici Group (hereinafter “RDM Group”),
which operates into the recycled cartonboard business.

In more detail, on October 26, 2021, (hereinafter, the “Acquisition Date”) Rimini BidCo S.p.A. (hereinafter “Rimini Bidco”
or the “Offeror”), a subsidiary of Rimini TopCo S.p.A., announced that it had finalized the purchase of approximately
67% of the issued and outstanding share capital of Reno De Medici S.p.A. from the Company’s two largest shareholders

- Cascades Canada ULC and Caisse de dépot et placement du Québec - at a price of €1.45 per share, thereby acquiring
control of the RDM Group.

Following said acquisition, the legal requirements were met for Rimini BidCo S.p.A. to launch a mandatory full takeover
bid on all of the issued and outstanding shares of Reno De Medici S.p.A. (the “Offer”) not already owned by the Offeror.
The Offer was filed with CONSOB (the Italian Market Authority) in November 2021, approved by resolution no.
22085/2021 on November 16, 2021 and successfully completed on December 17, 2021.

In view of the final results of the takeover bid, the Offeror having achieved a shareholding representing 99.94%, the
joint procedure concerning the ordinary shares of Reno De Medici S.p.A. still outstanding was started. The procedure
was completed on December 29, 2021, the date on which the ordinary shares of Reno De Medici S.p.A. were delisted
from Euronext Milano – STAR segment, and the Stock Exchanges of Madrid, Barcelona, Bilbao and Valencia (Bolsas de
Valores Españolas).

On December 16, 2022, Rimini BidCo S.p.A. was officially merged with its direct subsidiary Reno De Medici S.p.A., with
the latter as the surviving entity of the merger. Accordingly, Reno De Medici has assumed all rights and obligations of
Rimini BidCo. The merger has had accounting effects as of January 1, 2022.

These Consolidated Financial Statements were approved for publication by the Board of Directors of Rimini TopCo S.p.A.
on April 12, 2023.

The independent audit of these Consolidated Financial Statements is performed by PricewaterhouseCoopers S.p.A.

# 2. SUMMARY OF ACCOUNTING POLICIES

The main accounting criteria and principles applied in the preparation of these Consolidated Financial Statements as of
and for the period ended December 31, 2022 (hereinafter the "Consolidated Financial Statements") are listed below.

## 2.1 Basis of Preparation

These Consolidated Financial Statements were prepared in accordance with the International Financial Reporting
Standards (hereafter, “IFRS”) as issued by the International Accounting Standards Board (IASB) and adopted by the
European Union, in force as of December 31, 2022, and on the basis of the provisions of Legislative Decree 38/2005.

The designation “IFRS” also includes International Accounting Standards (“IAS”) as well as all the interpretations of the
International Financial Reporting Interpretations Committee, including those previously issued by the Standing
Interpretations Committee (“IFRIC” and “SIC”).

The Group applied the same accounting principles as for the Annual Financial Report as of December 31, 2021.


-----

**As of and for the year ended December 31, 2022 and as of and for the period ended December 31, 2021 (continued)**

The Consolidated Financial Statements were prepared on a going concern basis, as the Directors have verified the
absence of financial, management or other indicators that could indicate critical issues regarding the Group's ability to
meet its obligations in the foreseeable future, and in particular in the next 12 months. The description of the methods
through which the Group manages financial risks is contained in the following note 3 relating to "Risk management".

The Consolidated Financial Statements were prepared and presented in Euro, which represents the working currency
of the prevailing economic environment in which the Group operates. Unless otherwise indicated, all amounts included
in this document are expressed in thousands of Euro.

#### Presentation of the financial statements

The Consolidated Financial Statements and the related classification criteria adopted by the Group, as part of the
options envisaged by IAS 1 are presented below:

- The consolidated income statement was prepared by classifying operating costs by nature;

- The consolidated statement of comprehensive income, in addition to the result for the period shown in the income
statement, includes revenues and costs that are not recognized in the income statement for the period as required
by IFRS;

- The consolidated statement of financial position was prepared by classifying assets and liabilities according to the
"current / non-current" presentation;

- The consolidated statement of cash flows was prepared to show the cash flows derived from operating activities
according to the "indirect method".

The Consolidated Financial Statements were prepared on the basis of the conventional historical cost method, except
for the valuation of financial assets and liabilities, in which case the classification and measurement criteria set forth by
IFRS 9 are applied.

## 2.2 Principles of consolidation and equity accounting

###### SCOPE OF CONSOLIDATION

The consolidated financial statements include the financial statements of all subsidiaries, from the date on which
control is acquired until the date that such control ceases to exist.

The accounting period and the reporting date of the consolidated financial statements correspond to those of the

The criteria adopted by the Group for defining the scope of consolidation area and the related consolidation principles,
according to IFRS 10, are described below.

###### CONSOLIDATION PRINCIPLES

The financial position, results and cash flows of Rimini TopCo Group include the financial position, results and cash flows
of Rimini Topco S.p.A. and of the companies over which it has the control. The definition of control is not based solely
on the concept of legal ownership. According to IFRS 10, the definition of control is based on three elements: (a) power
to direct the investee; (b) exposure to or rights on variable returns resulting from involvement with the investee; (c)
capacity to utilize the power to influence the amount of these returns. IFRS 10 stipulates that in order to evaluate
whether it has control over the investee, an investor should focus only on activities that materially affect returns and
rights which are substantial, i.e. can be exercised in practice when important decisions have to be taken with regard to
the investee. The financial statements of subsidiaries are included in the Consolidated Financial Statements from the
date on which control is acquired until the date that such control ceases to exist. The portions of shareholders’ equity
and profit or loss attributable to minority interests are shown separately in the consolidated statement of financial
position, consolidated income statement, and consolidated statement of comprehensive income.


-----

**As of and for the year ended December 31, 2022 and as of and for the period ended December 31, 2021 (continued)**

The main consolidation principles adopted are as follows:

- the carrying amount of each investment consolidated on a line-by-line basis is eliminated against the related equity,
with the assets, liabilities, income and expense of the subsidiary being added to those of the Parent company,
regardless of the size of the investment; the shares of subsidiaries’ share capital and reserves and of subsidiaries’
profit or loss attributable to minority interests are shown separately in the consolidated statement of financial
position and the consolidated income statement;

- the acquisition of subsidiaries is accounted for using the purchase method as provided for by IFRS 3 (see “Business
Combinations”);

- all balances and transactions between Group companies are eliminated, as are any profits and losses (unless losses
indicate an impairment of the asset being transferred, requiring recognition) arising from commercial or financial
intragroup transactions not yet realized with third parties;

- any increases or decreases in a subsidiary’s equity arising from its post-acquisition results are recorded upon
elimination in the “Retained earnings (losses)” equity reserve;

- dividends distributed by Group companies are eliminated from the income statement upon consolidation.

In the event of loss of control, the Group will eliminate the assets and liabilities of the subsidiary, any third party
interests, and the other components of equity relative to the subsidiaries. The profit or loss from the loss of control will
be recognized in the profit or loss for the year. Any equity interest maintained in the former subsidiaries are
consolidated at fair value as from the date on which control was lost and, subsequently, is accounted for using the
method reported in the following paragraph “Investments” and cease to be consolidated on the date on which control
is transferred to third parties.

###### CONSOLIDATION OF FOREIGN COMPANIES

The financial statements of each affiliate are prepared in the currency of the economic area they mainly operate in (the
functional currency). All non-Euro assets and liabilities of foreign companies within the scope of consolidation are
translated using the exchange rates as of the reporting date (the current-rate method). Income and expenses are
translated at the average rate for the year. The exchange differences resulting from the use of this approach are
recognized in a dedicated equity reserve in “Other components of comprehensive income” until the disposal of the
investment.

###### EQUITY INVESTMENTS 

This item includes equity investments in associates and joint ventures, valued using the equity method, and investments
in other companies valued in accordance with IFRS 9.

Associates are companies over which the Group exercises significant influence, which is presumed to exist when the
Group holds between 20% and 50% of the voting rights of the associate company. Associates and joint ventures are


-----

**As of and for the year ended December 31, 2022 and as of and for the period ended December 31, 2021 (continued)**

initially recorded at cost and are subsequently valued using the equity method. Joint ventures are joint arrangements
whereby the parties that have joint control of the arrangements have rights to the net assets of the arrangements.

The Consolidated Financial Statements include the Group’s share of the results of associates in which its investments
are valued with equity method, from the date that significant influence or joint control is acquired until the date that it
ceases to exist. The Group’s share of unrealized profits from transactions between Group companies is eliminated.
Unrealized losses from transactions between Group companies are eliminated unless they represent actual impairment
of the asset transferred. Losses in excess of shareholders’ equity are accounted for insofar as the investor has a
commitment to the investee to abide by legal or constructive obligations or in any other way to cover its losses.

## 2.3 Valuation Criteria

The most significant accounting principles and valuation criteria used for the preparation of the Consolidated Financial
Statements are briefly described below.

###### BUSINESS COMBINATIONS

Business combinations in the scope of IFRS 3 are accounted for using the acquisition method. Under this method, the
consideration transferred in a business combination is measured at fair value, which is calculated as the sum of the
acquisition-date fair values of the assets transferred and liabilities assumed by the Group, and the equity instruments
issued in exchange for control of the acquiree. Acquisition-related costs are recognized in the income statement at the
time they are incurred.

The assets acquired and the liabilities assumed are recognized at their fair value as of the acquisition date. Goodwill is
measured as the excess of the aggregate of the consideration transferred in the business combination, the amount of
any non-controlling interest in the acquiree and the fair value of the acquirer’s previously held equity interest in the
acquiree (if any) over the net of the acquisition-date amounts of the identifiable assets acquired and the liabilities
assumed. The acquirer can finalize the allocation of fair values to individual assets and liabilities of the acquiree and
recognize new assets and liabilities arising from the business combination, within 12 months from the acquisition date
– the “Purchase Price Allocation” (PPA) process.

If the net of the acquisition-date amounts of the identifiable assets acquired and liabilities assumed exceeds the
aggregate of the consideration transferred, the amount of any non-controlling interest in the acquiree and the fair value
of the acquirer’s previously held interest in the acquiree (if any), the excess is recognized immediately in the income
statement as a bargain purchase gain.

At the acquisition date, the non-controlling interest is measured either at fair value or at the non-controlling interest’s
proportionate share of the acquiree’s identifiable net assets. The choice between the two methods is made on a
transaction-by-transaction basis. Any contingent consideration arrangement in the business combination is measured
at its acquisition date fair value and included as part of the consideration transferred in the business combination in
order to determine goodwill. Subsequent changes in the fair value are recognized in the income statement.

###### TANGIBLE ASSETS

Tangible fixed assets are stated at their original cost of purchase, production or contribution, including directly incurred
accessory costs required to bring an asset into a condition for use. The cost is reduced by accumulated depreciation
and any impairment. Costs for improvements, modernization and transformation incurred after the initial recognition
of the asset acquired or produced internally are ascribed to fixed assets and depreciated over their useful life, provided
they derive from separate analytical accounting measurements and when it is probable that the future economic
benefits expected from the asset will increase. Replacement costs of identifiable components of complex assets are
ascribed to fixed assets and depreciated over their useful life. The residual value of the replaced component is ascribed
to the income statement. Maintenance and repair costs are ascribed to the income statement in the year they are
incurred.

Depreciation is calculated on a straight-line basis over the estimated useful lives of assets, determined on the basis of
the period during which the asset will be used by the company. Land is not depreciated, even if acquired together with
buildings. The depreciation method applied to an asset (including estimate of its useful life) is reviewed at least at each
financial year-end and, if there has been a significant change in the expected pattern of consumption of the future
economic benefits embodied in the asset, the method shall be changed to reflect the changed pattern.


-----

**As of and for the year ended December 31, 2022 and as of and for the period ended December 31, 2021 (continued)**

The Group checks at least once a year if there is any indication that tangible assets have suffered impairment. If any
such indication exists, the recoverable amount of the asset is estimated to determine the extent of any impairment
loss, as described in the section “Impairment” below. Where it is not possible to estimate the recoverable amount of
an individual asset, the Company estimates the recoverable amount of the cash-generating unit to which the asset
belongs. An impairment loss is recognized when the recoverable amount is lower than the carrying amount. If the
reasons for previous write-downs no longer exist, the assets are revalued at the lower of the recoverable value and the
previous book value net of depreciation that would have been recorded in the absence of a write-down, with the
adjustment being made on the income statement.
